She could make lists until the coffee cooled. She could balance ledgers while thunder rolled. She had made a company out of a threadbare idea and an empty spare room, and sometimes when she forgot to breathe she would remember that, would hold it like a coin. But lately the numbers had been stubborn as nettles.

"Three shipments stuck, one client audibly breathing into my ear to intimidate me," she told the empty air and the one small rosemary bush that Marius had coaxed onto the sill. "Singura veselie, rosemary is alive. Good. Bine."

The rosemary wavered. Below, the courtyard rattled with the sounds of buckets, hose, an old radio tuned to a station that played songs from the nineties and advertisements for paint. Marius had the kind of face that didn't reveal much unless he wanted it to. He wore a cap even in sun and a jacket through spring, and every day he swept the same arcs of dust as if they were lines he alone could see. He nodded when he sensed eyes on him—not looking up, not exactly—like an old horse. He had been hired by the building association and somehow ended up trusted with keys to lockers, boiler room, a shed where he stacked sapling stakes, old wires, sacks of gravel. People said he slept somewhere behind the tool wall when it rained.

At the corner of the kitchen table, Ileana's phone blinked with an email alert like a small heartbeat. Her investor, Sorin, had sent a message at midnight: we need to discuss direction. He always wrote like he was dictating to a mirror. The direction he wanted leaned toward importing cheaper things for faster money, whittling costs until the spine of the business snapped. She had resisted for months, and now they had their first true fight scheduled. She set the coffee down and decided there was no more delaying the tiny errand she'd invented for herself—Obor market, just for twenty minutes, to buy three lemons and maybe something else. Something her hands could carry that wasn't a contract.

On the tram she stood, because everyone stood, men pretending they hadn't seen her, women with elbows sharper than knives. She watched the city blur and wished it would slow like breath. At the market's edge the air changed—onions, fried dough, clatter—and then she saw a table that made her stop, made everything inside her slow until the noise deferred. The table overflowed with flowers, but not flowers: paper—crepe, tissue, streamers cut into fringes—twisted and dyed into peonies, carnations, scraggly little daisies with yellow centers that were too cheerful to be real. The woman behind the table had bracelets up both arms. Her hair was threaded with ribbon; she had a missing tooth and the most patient eyes.

Ileana's fingers reached, ridiculous. One rose, deep red, curled like a tongue. She didn't touch it. She was thirty-six, she knew what a day ought to look like. Numbers. Lemon. Maybe cigarettes, if the stress convinced her into the old habit. Not paper roses.

"Frumoasă, nu?" the woman said, tipping her head. "You can touch. They like it when you touch. Otherwise they think they are just fake, săracele."

"I didn't bring cash," Ileana lied, and then felt her wallet heavy in her bag. She didn't want to be pulled into a conversation. She didn't want to explain why she was paused here like a child at a circus window. "Maybe next week."

"Next week they will be different." The woman pinched the edge of a petal and teased it outward until it cupped perfectly. "Today they are this shape. Tomorrow they will be that shape. Because of your hands. Because of how you look at them."

"Soft sales pitch," Ileana said, and the woman laughed. It was a low, generous laugh that rolled between the stalls, scandalizing a fishmonger who had spent two hours arranging his sardines by angle. "I'm sorry. I'm late."

"Five minutes," the woman said. "I show you how to make one? Free. For your hands, yes? They are kind hands. I can see."

"I do logistics," Ileana said, and felt a strange flinch at how that sounded right then, a gray word in a place full of nail polish and frying oil and fruit. "Between Constanța and... this." She drew a line in the air. "I don't make. I order. I nag."

"You breathe," the woman said, unfazed. "That's enough. Sit."

It was an insult to hurry past someone who had offered generosity so directly. Ileana sat on the rickety plastic chair and looked at the woman's hands. They were nicked, strong, motherly. "I'm Luminita," she said, and pushed a wad of crepe paper at Ileana. "Stretch it. Look. Not too much. It tears if you pull like you pull onto traffic on Ștefan cel Mare."

"I never—" Ileana started to protest, then laughed at the accuracy. Her hands obeyed the paper, making a saucer shape she didn't know she could make. Fold. Pinch. Twist wire. Turn slowly. She did as she was told. The petals formed without drama. A flower with inexact perfection—hers—looked up at her as if expecting to be named.

"You see?" Luminita's bracelets clinked softly. "Everyone thinks it's only for cemeteries. Or for some country wedding where the bride's uncle has money for a B-series but not for tulips. They say it's kitsch. They all say: hă-hă, paper. It can't breathe. They say a lot. But look." She held the flower up and turned it so the stall's shadow moved over it like a cloud. "It catches the same light."

"It's beautiful." Ileana blurted it, surprised by the ring of truth, like a glass he had struck. "It's… Not just beautiful. It feels like the thing stands in for time. I mean—"

"You talk like a woman who has argued for something until she forgot her own ears," Luminita said gently. "Here. Take it. And if you want, Thursday night, a small class in the community room under the stadium. Ten lei. I will teach you to cut the fringe for peonies. Bring scissors that will forgive you."

"I have... I have meetings," Ileana said. "I'm sorry. I..."

"Your face says 'meetings' and your hands say 'petals.' Decide which one you listen to later." Luminita winked. "Thursday we are there. If you come, you come."

She put the flower in her tote like a bottle bomb and forced herself to move, to buy lemons that suddenly looked anemic compared to the paper bloom, to contact a driver about a delivery, to avoid looking back. On the tram home she stuck her nose near the paper and inhaled. It smelled like dye and dust, nothing of rose, and yet her throat strained as if it might find sweetness. She shook her head, ashamed of the sentimentality, almost angry at herself for having been the kind of woman who could be kidnapped by red. It was twelve minutes of her life. She would forget.

She did not forget. That night, after the email exchange with Sorin turned flinty, after a client called to say that he had found a cheaper supplier in Poland and maybe they could talk next quarter, after her mother phoned from Focșani to examine the holes in her life—"Thirty-six, Ileana. The neighbor's daughter has two children and a lavatory with marble. And you? Ansamblul tău? Apartments are expensive now. I saw on TV"—after all of that, she took the flower out of her bag and put it on the kitchen table. The kitchen light made the red deepen. It was a modest thing, glued, imperfect, stubborn.

"Well?" she demanded of it, as if it were a negotiator. "What?"

The rosemary plant didn't answer. Neither did the flower. The silence made space. She opened her laptop and googled paper flowers, then crepe paper, then flori din hârtie like she remembered from childhood, when she had watched her grandmother's neighbor, a Roma seamstress, make coin garlands and paper blossoms for funerals. You made a tree, they said, for the dead. You hung sweets and bright paper birds, and after the ceremony children tore them down and ran away with mouths sticky with ritual. She felt something in her chest tip.

On Thursday night she went.

She told herself it was research. Logistics of a different product. She told herself she would be in the building for twenty minutes, and then she would dash to a late dinner with a client who needed handholding. She told herself she was not the kind of person who was swayed by small wonders. She told herself many things and carried her grandmother's old sewing scissors in her bag like talisman. The community room smelled of rain and old gym shoes. Luminita had dragged in folding tables and her box of paper, and four other women already sat, arms crossed, daring themselves not to cry.

"We don't have to be sentimental," Luminita said, as if she'd heard every thought. "We can make peonies and curse our exes and pay attention. That's enough."

They cut. They fringe-cut everything. Tissue into streamers, streamers into fringes so fine they stuck to their lips. They rolled and twisted and slid stems into green tape. Luminita kept repeating her one instruction—breathe, breathe—and when the tips of Ileana's fingers stained pink, she felt something like mercy. There was accomplishment that didn't involve a delivery window, a discount, a signature, a power suit. There was shape made out of flatness. Inside the bloom, she could see wrinkles she'd left like fingerprints.

"I used to do nails," a woman across the table announced, unwinding a ribbon of white. "People looked at their phones the whole time. I thought: no more. These, they look back at you. They don't blink."

"At my wedding," said another, "my husband's aunt put paper flowers in the icons. My grandmother said it was a bad sign." She shrugged. "Thirty years and a mortgage later, I think she was wrong."

"I make them for graves too," Luminita said without flinching. "I don't think it's bad. I think people need a color that doesn't leave them the next day."

When Ileana got home, past eleven, Marius was closing the courtyard shed, the last thing he did before disappearing into whatever his life was. He smelled like wet leaves and cigarette smoke and the sharp tin of the old radio. The hose lay coiled like a sleeping snake. He nodded when he heard her step, as if he had known the pattern of her shoes for months.

"Is that paper?" he asked, pointing with his chin at the bouquet peeking from her bag.

"It is," she said. "Apparently I am twelve years old again."

"No. When we were little," he said, unusually talkative, "my mother made them for parastas. For forty days, for a year. People laughed too. They said, why not real roses? She did both. She said the paper ones don't ask for water. The dead like things that don't ask." He looked away at nothing, at the oleanders that never flowered in Bucharest because someone always forgot to bring them inside for winter. "We had a dog that used to steal one and run. He loved the wire. He thought it was a stick that fought back."

"You know how to make them?"

"I know how to hold them," he said. His voice had that flatness that turned all statements into fact. "And I know the wind that blows here. By morning if you leave them out they’ll be in the gutter. The kids play football. They won't see. If you like them, keep them inside. People mistake carelessness for malice."

"I always do," she said, surprised that truth had slid out. Maybe it was the hour. "I always think the missed call means someone hates me."

"You are not so important." He said it without meanness, and it stabbed then soothed. "No one has time to hate you. They only forget. This is better. I like the red."

Upstairs, she arranged them in a glass jar because she didn't own a proper vase. The old jar had a label half-peeled, and the glue was gummy under her thumb. She put the arrangement on her desk where, in the morning, it would catch the window's pale. She slept as if the entire day had not been made of sand.

The morning did not honor her with ease. Sorin arrived at the office with his expensive sad smile and the kind of cologne that left the room ten minutes after he did. He moved chair legs, looked at the flower jar, and chuckled.

"What are we selling now," he said, "whimsy?"

"Don't start," Ileana said, hating how small she sounded. "They're a—present."

"We need to talk margins," he said, as if the jar had not been there. "We need to talk pivot, Ileana."

"I am bone-tired of your words," she snapped. "Pivot. Synergy. The thing you want me to do is also simple to say: cheap. And I can't be that. Not now."

"We can be out," he said, looking toward the window the way he always did when he wanted to make an exit sound like an offer. "Sell the last containers, pay off what we can, let it all set. There is a health products distributor that's buying. They are expanding. Supplements, tinctures. If we—"

"Do I look like a woman who can sleep if she gives up?" she said. The flower in her eye's corner soothed nothing, couldn't even be used as a shield. "Don't talk to me about health products. I have eaten crackers for dinner all week. I don't want to sell gel caps."

"You are sentimental lately," Sorin laughed, and it wasn't kind. "Is there a man? Is there a—"

"Get out," she said, very softly. "Please. Or drop it. We can argue later. Today I need to live out my day and not make a permanent decision that will make me disappointed in myself for five years."

He threw up his hands and gave her three hours, a mercy he would later charge her for. She sat, pressed her fingers between her eyes until little stars burst there, and let numbers line up like soldiers. She emailed and re-emailed. She told herself, when the room dimmed, that she was holding. For now.

Her assistant, Mara, who was twenty-seven and never wasted feelings on things she could fix with sarcasm, leaned in with a box of staples and the look people wear when they're about to tell you a story you didn't consent to hear. "My cousin saw you at Obor," she said. "She said you were sitting with a woman who sells those tacky flowers. Her words, not mine." Mara put the staples down and rolled her eyes at the jar. "My grandmother used to say paper flowers are either for brothels or for the cemetery. Choose your clientele."

"We have such a rich heritage," Ileana said dryly. "Why are we even in the European Union? We have proverbs. We're full of advice."

"Tissue paper gives me hives," Mara said. "Don't ask me why. You're allowed your eccentricities. Better paper than cats."

The teasing was kinder than the laugh had been. Even so, by lunch, Ileana hid the jar under her desk as if it were contraband. She walked to Baker's on the corner and ate a pretzel she didn't taste. Outside, a man with string-straight hair asked her for a cigarette, and she shook her head. On the way back a poster slapped the side of a bus: a baby smiling down at a bottle of cough syrup. The word "homeopathy" shrank and enlarged as the bus moved. It was a word she'd only thrown at in conversation as a joke, a reflex of skepticism. Water with a memory. She had pointed and laughed. But there it was, blue letters you could almost lean on, and something in her remembered her grandmother's cupboard full of tinctures with all the labels written by hand. After a fever, a drop under the tongue, the swell of sleep like wind under a kite.

"Don't be ridiculous," she told herself, hearing Mara's eye roll in her head. "You are not going to go into sugar pills. You are not going to be a witch." Still, when she got home she typed the word into the search bar, then erased it, then retyped it and fell into the rabbit hole of cure-alls and quacks and earnest believers and studies with sample sizes so small you could hold them in a palm. It didn't matter. It was the feeling that did. The feeling that there might exist a way to help, however flawed, that wasn't spreadsheets or ports or Sorin's talk.

On Saturday, when she carried a paper bouquet to her friend Anca's daughter's birthday party, she did it with shame hot on her cheeks. She had never been embarrassed about taste; she had never been the woman who brought the wrong thing. But it was raining and the party was in a two-room flat in Militari, and Anca's mother came to the door with her hair wrapped in a towel and took the bouquet like it was a stranger who might steal silver. Inside, the children screamed at a purple-clad clown, sugar staining their teeth, and a woman by the window whispered "mamaie, look, paper" like an insult. The room coughed out a laugh. Anca hugged her and whispered, "It's perfect," fierce enough to make Ileana believe it for a flicker, and then and then they put the bouquet near the TV, and the fourth child to have a balloon popped cried, and the clown tried to do magic with a coin. The paper flowers didn't wilt. Something about their stubbornness disturbed Ileana. She wanted them to be tender enough to fail.

On the way out it had stopped raining, the pavement spreading silver underfoot. In the courtyard of her building Marius was puzzling over the hinge on the big iron gate, throwing his weight against it in frustrated increments. "It moans like a sick thing," he grunted.

"It sings like an opera," she said, because she couldn't manage a complaint. "I brought you a piece of cake. Made of butter and regret."

"Regret is my favorite," he said without smiling, accepting the plastic plate. "You look angry."

"I hate when people whisper. It's like gnats. Too small to squash. Do you know what I mean?"

"Yes," he said, and for perhaps the first time since she had met him, his face shifted, as if the underneath had moved. "I do."

In the next week, small things turned and turned. An email thread that had been anemic warmed. A client returned, sheepish, because Poland hadn't sent what they promised. "Fine," she wrote back, and then deleted the word "fine" because it felt like she was forgiving. She allowed herself coffee at noon. She let her phone ring without pouncing. She told Sorin she would meet him for a last talk at a cafe with walls painted dark as licorice. For the first time, she offered him a choice: buy her out or let her buy him. He was so surprised he did not speak for seconds. That seemed like progress.

On Thursday, her hands full of crepe forests, she walked out of Luminita's class and into the kind of evening Bucharest sometimes produced like an apology. The clouds had thinned enough to let bruised light through, and above the stadium's concrete, swifts reeled as if someone had shaken the sky. On the tram she stood again, pressed to the door by a suited man who breathed like a bull, and watched a boy of ten press his forehead to the window to fog it. He wrote a word into the fog. It was a name. The girl next to him blushed and pushed him in the arm and then wrote, below it, a small flower. The petals were lopsided. It was not exactly pretty. It was the best thing Ileana had seen all week.

She slept badly—thunder took a giant step across the city—and in the morning she went down to the courtyard early because she had left something in her car and also because she wanted air. Marius was there in the gray, tying a sapling to a stake with soft pantyhose strips. He had a cigarette stuck to the side of his mouth. He looked like he had been awake too long.

"These," he said without preamble, tapping the nail on the stake, "are too thin. They will snap when the wind decides to come for real. I'll find better."

"Does the wind ask your permission?" she teased, and then swallowed it. There was something in him today. A tension in the hand. The radio was off. The gate was ajar. A stray dog slept under the bench with its belly up like a question.

"Sometimes it does," he said. "If you know its name."

"Come to the market with me this weekend," she said impulsively. "We can buy better stakes. And—no, sorry, I don't usually. Ask people to spend Saturday with me."

He looked at her as if she had said something very strange. Then he nodded once. "Also we buy wire. Not the soft one that twists like sugar. The real one, with a bite. For your flowers." His face had gone unreadable again.

No one had asked her about her flowers as if they were anything other than hobby, as if she might require a better grade of supplies. It pierced her. "Yes," she managed. "For those."

At the market, he moved like a man who had directions from a map inside his bones, even though Ileana had never seen him out of the courtyard. They walked past stalls selling shoes that looked embarrassed to be shoes, past a table of cabbage pyramids so precise you could have split a hair with the lines between leaves. A vendor in a denim vest asked Marius if he wanted to bet on a fight; he ignored him. He chose wire with the way he chose his words: only when necessary; no ornament. Ileana bought paper in colors she had no names for. At Luminita's stall, the teacher pretended not to see Marius until he tipped his cap and then she laughed like a shout.

"Eh, Marius," she said. "Look at you. Still choosing the straightest staves. Leave the girl the curved ones. It makes prettier stems."

"You know each other?" Ileana asked, startled.

"Of course," Luminita said easily, using her chin to pry open a new box of green tape. "He used to bring his mother here. She would sit and I would take her lists and sometimes she would buy nothing, only talk. She had a back that hurt like winter. She told good jokes. You still tell her jokes?"

"They were hers," he said, and that was that. There was a small silence in which the market seemed to breathe. Then Luminita thrust an extra roll of crepe into Ileana's bag. "For luck," she said, as if luck were a material you could lay by, if you were sensible enough to carry the right bag.

Back in the courtyard, they cut the stakes, and Marius hammered them into the dirt as if killing something invisible. He sweat, but he didn't remove the jacket. He had a scar on his wrist that looked like river-lace. She wanted to ask him where it came from, but she also wanted to keep living in a place where not everything had to be answered at once. Instead she handed him slices of bread with olive paste that she had made at midnight with a spoon and a small sort of fury.

"My father said paper flowers were for girls who cried too much," she said, as if she were commenting on weather. "I think maybe I am done taking orders from ghosts."

"You could be careful," he said, turning his face upward to judge the way the wind recorded itself in the pine tips. "People like to run their mouths. They can be… It is not only laughter. It can cut. You pretend not to bleed and then at night. And then at night."

"And then?" she asked, and he shook his head, finished his slice, put the plate on the bench, and something in him closed like the shed door, tidy, final.

That evening the building association had one of its meetings in the ground-floor hallway, which smelled of damp and a neighbor's onion soup. Cătălin, who had moved in three months ago with a white toothbrush and a plan to buy the whole block if his imagination allowed, brought printouts with colored graphs. He wanted to cut down the courtyard trees because "roots are disruptive" and because "shade makes mold." He wanted to pave. He wanted to add parking. He wanted, mostly, to see himself reflected in a glazed surface.

"Do we want more dust?" Ileana said, surprising herself with the force of her voice. "More heat? We already breath in cement. I like to see birds that are not pigeons. Is that so frivolous? Are we—"

"Ah," Cătălin said, in the tone that had prompted boys to fight him in school but which his shoulders had allowed him to avoid, "the lady with the... the craft. How sweet. Perhaps we could hang your paper bouquets from the lampposts in the new parking lot. Artisanal."

"Or we could plant geraniums," she said. "Those red ones you like when it is the election." Laughter tipped toward her, then away when his face soured. People were cowards; she didn't blame them. Their mortgages were knives they kept in their pockets.

Marius stood at the edge of the gathering, his hands behind his back, his chin tilted in a way that wasn't quite defiant. He did not speak. He did not have to; he had a way of standing that made lawyers and men like Cătălin push their voices harder, as if they must make something happen to justify themselves. In the end, they voted to do nothing, to "revisit in six months" which was to say, to let time decide or to let something quieter find them. It fascinated her—that sometimes the bravest action was to refuse action, to sit in the weeds with your throat quiet and your hands closed around a thing you did not want to relinquish.

Afterwards, she found him at the gate, fitting a piece of rubber into the hinge so the moan softened. "You did not speak," she said.

"I am the gardener," he said. It was the first time she had heard him call himself that. "They think my vote is leaves. I save my speech for other uses."

"What uses?"

"For the day when someone wants to hurt something I can put my body in front of," he said, still in that flat tone, and for the first time since she'd known him, a glint of steel showed under the dirt. It frightened and thrilled her to see it.

The next weeks slipped, but not away. Mara came in with allergies and left with a bouquet that made her sneeze less. "It's like it scares the pollen," she said, amazed. Anca sent a photo of her daughter holding the red rose like a microphone. Luminita introduced a new student at class, a man with hands that shook and eyes that had seen too many dawns.

"People laugh at you?" he asked Ileana, when she offered him the green tape like communion.

"They have always laughed at me," she said, smiling, "for one reason or another. I am a factory of reasons."

"Then we are three," he said, and pointed to himself, to the paper in his hand, to the evening spread flat outside the window like a sheet. They bent their heads together over a center of wire and glue and breath.

Her mother phoned again on a Sunday when television shows hurt the air. "Your cousin Costel says he saw you at the market," she announced, as if presenting a nurse with a fever chart. "He says you were buying carnival supplies. Are you having midlife crisis?"

"I am having my life," Ileana said, washing strawberries one by one. "Mami. I am having it."

"What if you get a virus from those papers? They come from somewhere dirty. China. I'm joking, don't start. Listen. The neighbor's daughter. Marble. It's... no, I will not go into it again. Listen, they put sugar in everything, what do I know."

"I'm practicing being wrong," Ileana said, lightly now. "It warms me at night."

"You joke too much," her mother sighed. "Make the sign of the cross. Say a psalm. Be serious one day."

When they met, Sorin tried to charm her out of the mood she had set like a table. He failed, because she did not reciprocate, and charm needs a second to matter. In the end, there was a document. There was the signature he thought she would not be brave enough to ask for. There was the way the air in the cafe felt different after it was done—thinner, full of particles, as if she could hear her own lungs. She hid in the bathroom for a minute, two, because she had trained herself to leave rooms before she cried. She didn't. She splashed water on her face like every actress in a show, and then she laughed at herself there, in the tarnished mirror.

When she came out the day's light had turned gold like a trinket. She walked home the long way, past an old apothecary with green-painted shelves and brown bottles with Latin names that pretended they knew more than they did. The woman behind the counter scowled. "We close in five," she said. "If you want something, be quick."

"I don't know what I want," Ileana said honestly, as if the apothecary could spare the time to solve more than a headache.

"Then you're not buying," the woman said, but her mouth's corner betrayed her, a small kindness. "Try tomorrow. At least bring me a problem to solve. I hate tourists."

She went to sleep with the crepe paper folded at the foot of her bed like extra sheets. It softened the night. She dreamed a tree with white birds sitting where the leaves would be, and in the dream she could not tell if the birds were alive or made of paper, and it didn't matter because the tree hummed as if it wanted for nothing.

In the dark morning the air felt wrong. She knew it as she poured coffee. The trams sounded louder. The neighbor's dog didn't bark. Even the rosemary did not look pleated with life. On the stairs on her way down she met an older woman she had never seen in her life; the woman wore a sweater buttoned in the wrong order and gave Ileana the solemn nod you might give someone in a waiting room.

At the bottom of the stairs, the courtyard was empty in a way that emptied her. The gate was ajar, but not for air. The radio was on but low, as if someone had placed a hand over its mouth. And there was Marius, sitting on the bench, both hands on his knees like a man waiting for judgment. The stray dog lay under his feet, eyes on him, a guard who didn't know what to guard.

"What?" Ileana said, not whispering because whispering would make it too real. "Is something wrong? Are you—" She stopped. The air was wrong because something had happened. It hadn't happened to her. It was in the smell of condensing breath above dirt. It was in the way the buildings seemed to lean.

Marius looked up at her, and for once his face showed something and did not hide it fast enough. He looked like a man who had done something that could not be undone. He looked like the hinge of the gate, metal cracking around a hole, not yet broken, giving.

"Later," he said, and she heard the word fold as if loaded with wet. "Later I will ask you if you can make something white."

She sat beside him without touching. The dog put its chin on her shoe and exhaled as if explaining something to her patiently, in a language she should have known. The old radio murmured to itself. The plants were just plants. They stood. They did not know that anything had changed. That was the cruelty and the blessing.

"I have a class," she said, to say anything.

"You're learning to make petals," he said. There was nothing mocking in it. "Good. Learn."

She sat with him until the concierge began to rattle keys and unlock doors and the city's noise slipped back into place like a coin into a slot. She went upstairs and washed her hands twice, as if guilt were a smell. She returned to the table and looked at the red rose in the jar, which had started to lean like an old man. She took it out and rewrapped the base with stronger tape, then made a note in a small notebook: better wire. She wrote it three times, as if the insistence could keep anything upright that wanted very much to fall.

When she finally went to class, late, Luminita looked at her with that slow, telling gaze that had undone her at Obor. "We make white today," she said, simply, and started to teach them the kind of flowers you took into quiet places where people sat with their hands between their knees and listened to the air working hard.

On the way home, she walked past the apothecary, and this time she went in. The woman behind the counter recognized her enough to soften. "Today?" she said.

"Today I bring a problem," Ileana said. "I don't know if it can be solved with anything you have. But I want to learn names. Of herbs. Of drops. Of anything that helps. Even if it is only a story. I can pay for good stories."

"Sometimes stories are the only things we have to fill our bottles," the woman said, reaching for a ledger. "Start with chamomile. For sleep. For the first night after. Then we talk again."

That night, she put the chamomile under her tongue as if it were a truth. She sat with her scissors threatening silence. She finished three white carnations that were not perfect and looked exactly like the thing she could offer. And the next morning, when she went down, Marius had not slept. He was there, his cap on the bench beside him, the dog under the bench, the gate's hinge quiet. He looked at the white flowers as if they were offering him a kind of grammar. He did not ask questions. She did not tell him a thing. There were other voices for that. But when he stood, the weight he carried made sense in the way that gravity makes sense: not fair, not kind, only true.

"You have good hands," he said, unpracticed gratitude. "They make order out of—"

"Paper," she said. "I make order out of paper."

"It is more than paper," he said, and then looked past her, toward the street, toward a siren that had decided to hesitate at the corner, as if waiting for permission, and toward a morning that had already started to break over its own bleeding edge.

The day after the siren stalled at the corner, the Dâmbovița tried on a brightness it couldn't keep. The wind prodded bits of ash off the water, and a plastic bottle moved like a small, stubborn animal. Ileana watched the river while coffee sought its level in the mug. She thought of how, as a child, she had believed the river was a ribbon that someone might pick up and shake to get the city to behave. The thought made her smile in that dry, private way she had when she wanted to test herself for softness. She took her notebook and wrote a list of things that might be needed when someone died, surprising herself with the neatness of her handwriting: candles, sugar cubes, plastic cups, napkins, coffee, colivă, towels, black scarves, paper icons, matches. She added to the list: white. She closed the notebook and felt, in her capable way, that making a list was a small way of putting a sheet over something you didn't yet have the strength to look at.

When she reached the courtyard, the bench held the shape of someone who'd sat a long time and gotten up carefully. The stray dog had claimed the sliver of sun on the concrete and was playing at sleep, one ear cocked like a radio antenna. The gate's hinge had been tamed to a purr. Marius was not there, but the hose lay rolled with military attention, and a plastic bag of bread heels hung from the nail where he left things for the pigeons when he didn't feel like tolerating their greed. On the noticeboard where the association posted its threats about overdue fees, someone had pinned a black ribbon under a handwritten name: Maria G. No dates. People were always stingy with the dates, as if the numbers would make the loss expire faster. Ileana stood with her hands flat on the cool mailbox metal. She whispered, because there was no one to overhear and because saying a thing out loud sometimes lodged it properly in the throat: Dumnezeu s-o ierte.

She meant to go upstairs and sit on her hands until they admitted what they wanted to do, but instead she found her feet performing a memory she didn't know she had. She walked to the apothecary with the mean-faced woman and bought a stack of beeswax candles that smelled faintly of smoked apples. She went to the supermarket and bought bad coffee that made better coffee taste like mercy, sugar by the kilo, napkins with flowers printed in a red too cheerful for the occasion. She texted Luminita: need white, many, quickly, can we do pom? Luminita wrote back: come, I have wire and patience. She texted Marius with her usual reluctance to cross a line. He answered nothing and then a single word: later. The word had become a bridge; she didn't mind crossing it without knowing what stood on the other side.

At the market, Luminita had set her table differently, a small act that made the regulars glance and then look away. The reds and ultraviolet candies of last week were gone, replaced with creams and whites and the faint powder blue that old grievers liked, because they remembered the glaze of the Madonna in their grandmother's kitchen. Luminita had brought in her daughter-in-law to help, a woman with a braid like a thick rope who laughed under her breath when the taxi drivers made jokes that were so tired even the pigeons didn't bother to turn their heads. They cut circles and ovals, they tore strips, they stamped fringes so fine they whispered. Ileana's hands remembered to breathe before she did. The paper lifted under her thumbs as if it wanted to become what she wanted. It felt indecent, to be given so much obedience by a flat thing.

"You have mother's hands today," Luminita observed without sentiment, as if she were remarking on the weather. "Not in the sense of babies. In the sense of care. Put that into the wire. It holds."

"His mother," Ileana said, to see what the words did out in the air. "I met her without meeting."

"She liked to watch the pigeons chew without swallowing," Luminita said. "She said, see, even birds get drunk on plenty. She faked a limp one year to get out of going to some cousin's wedding in Pantelimon. She hated the way people looked at her pain like it was an anecdote. I liked her. I told her finally that the limp was an absurdity. She said, I know, but it helps me gods and neighbors equally. Hold the tape closer. Your stems are loose."

They worked without explaining to anyone else what they were doing. They made lilies that looked less like lilies and more like the idea that lilies wanted to preserve of themselves. They made crepe bells that would clink with the slightest wind. The pom they began to build was a small tree of wire and decency; it would be dressed with apples polished until they wore the faces of ten people; it would hold pretzels threaded with red string, money pinned in the old-fashioned way to paper leaves with the heads of dead kings looking off into a better distance. Ileana had a superstition about doing things right when it mattered; she imagined ghosts took notes the way professors did, head tilted, pencil held lightly, patient with you up to a point and then not patient at all.

When she carried the first armful of white through the courtyard, the dog got up and followed her like a senior usher. Men she had only ever known as men with cigarettes and pilled sweaters came forward to take the bags without cheerful talk. In the stairwell, someone had scrubbed the graffiti off the landing without any announcement or threat against future graffiti; it shone, for once, like a clean thought. The elevator had an out-of-order sign in handwriting that looked like a child's, and beneath it someone had drawn a cross with equal arms, as if God could be balanced by care.

The apartment where death had arrived wore no special costume. It smelled of boiled potatoes and ironed shirts. The curtains were pulled halfway, as if compromise could still be brokered with light. In the front room, the table kidneyed against a wall held the framed photograph that would stand in for a presence that had gone elsewhere. A young woman in a summer dress, a boy next to her making a serious face like men do when they think a camera is also a question. Ears that were not shy about themselves, a mouth that had decided early to be kind and had suffered for it in the small ways only kindness measures.

Marius was taller in that room. Grief steels a spine in a way that makes it look like someone else's. He nodded at her, and the gesture gave her permission to move. She unwrapped the flowers, counting without thinking—twelve, twenty, thirty—and set them in the places where, by custom, roses might have gone if money had wanted to brag. An auntly neighbor crossed herself and said, softly, "Paper? Eh, well. Better than nothing." Another woman, toes in folded sandals, touched one of the white bells the way you test a bruise. "They keep," she said, and then looked embarrassed to have said it like a compliment.

When they brought in the pom and dressed it with apples and small packages of biscuits and sugar, someone began to tell stories. It begins like that in rooms where the Christian calendar bends the day into meaning even when the city outside refuses to. A man tried to make a joke and failed and then cried into his fist, ashamed of the water. The priest came and went, leaving the smell of wax and a corridor of words through which the neighbors moved, order restored by syllables no one pretended to fully understand. Ileana found herself pouring coffee like a waitress, counting cups, rolling sugar between her fingers to keep from wringing her hands. Her own mother would have approved of her competence and scolded her for her pride in it.

Marius did not speak until late, when the room had settled into the murmur of women who were not done saying what needed to be said and men who had run out of acceptable places to put their hands. He stood next to the pom as if it had become a close friend. He touched a paper petal and made no show of it. "She liked white," he said, as if to the tree. "She kept a tablecloth folded under the other tablecloths, for when the right guest came. She said maybe no one is the right guest, but perhaps the impulse is enough. Şi cu asta… That’s life." He looked at the photograph and did not look back for a while.

Ileana edged closer only to ask, quietly, whether he wanted her to take the pom to the cemetery or leave it for the forty days, a question she only knew to ask because she had sat in rooms with her grandmother when someone went and a pine plank made the table longer. He glanced at her mouth, not her eyes, and said, "Forty. Children will come. Good. Let them pull. Let them learn to want with their hands. The apples we give away. The paper we can keep. The dog will eat the pretzels if we leave him alone five minutes."

After the neighbors drifted and the last ring of coffee cups clinked into the sink, she went home and slept with the smell of candles in her hair. She dreamed of a white room with a window that looked not over the city but over a field where wind kept turning the tall grass like a great hand. In the morning her nose stung as if she had cried, though she was not entirely sure she had. She made a list of tasks that had nothing to do with death, because life required that you give it equal time even when it was rude.

At the office, Mara had lined up invoices with the efficiency of a bored cat arranging trophies. "We have Belgium back," she announced as if returning a loaned coat. "Poland sent them shoes that were left-right-left. Also, Sorin wrote three emails in a row with the words 'final offer' in them. I ignored the first two. The third came with a smiley face, so I wrote a paragraph about compliance and attached a photo of a baby goat. He hasn't answered."

"I signed," Ileana said, and the word went out into the room like a bird that wasn't sure it wanted to leave. "This week. It's done."

Mara blinked and then whistled; her respect had always presented itself as irony, but now something else stood behind it, a steadiness that she rarely showed. "So it's you alone. Congratulations or condolences?"

"Both," Ileana admitted. "We owe less than we fear and more than we like. But if I fail, it will be mine. I think I wanted that. I think I was tired of being asked to arrange myself around another person's idea of profit."

"Look at you," Mara said, tipping her chin toward the jar on the shelf, where two white bells had migrated overnight as if the flowers traveled in sleep. "With your crafts and your kingdom. Try not to pay salaries with peonies."

"I can pay salaries with the things peonies taught me," Ileana said, surprising herself. She sat and wrote three emails that would either save the month or burden it. Then she opened the spreadsheet with the column that always made her stomach climb her spine, and she looked at it until the numbers behaved.

On a slow afternoon, when the city dozed in its own heat and the office fan hummed like a plain song, she walked back to the apothecary. The woman behind the counter wore a new blouse with daisies embroidered at the neck; the daisies were uneven, which made Ileana like them more. "Today," the woman said, before being asked, "you need linden. And a small bottle of valerian if you are not offended by the smell of old socks. It helps when sleep curls under the bed and refuses to come out."

"I am learning to name things," Ileana said. "Chamomile. Tei. Sunătoare. I want to be careful, not become one of those women who sprinkle drops and think it absolves them of kindness. I want to know what is story and what is sap."

The woman snorted, amused. "You are a rare bird. Most people come here to buy a license for their panic. They want religion in vials. I can provide tea and a scolding. The rest is between you and your breath."

"Do you ever sell the little white pills?" Ileana asked, and braced, not for the answer but for the argument.

"I sell anything that won't harm and might persuade," the woman said with a weary pragmatism that Ileana admired. "If a man sleeps because he believes in sugar with a job, I will not wake him to instruct him. Bring me your problems with borders. The ones with no edges are for another shop. Or for the priest. Or for your paper."

The days filled with the kind of work that, if written on a calendar, looked like a list of small defeats and small mercies. She learned to nod differently when clients threatened to leave; the nod said, that is your choice, and also, I am not terrified of it. She rewrote a contract to fit the truth rather than the hope. She calculated how many bouquets of paper peonies would equal one container's profit and then laughed at herself for the stupidity of the math and then recalculated because sometimes foolish exercises teach you where your stubbornness hides. She took three orders for corporate gifts; a law firm wanted white lilies for their conference room, because irony entertained them; a nursing home wanted pink carnations, because the residents had opinions about roses that went back to a summer in '78 and who was worthy of them; a wedding planner called to tell her paper was out and plastic in, and Ileana said "no thank you" and hung up with a satisfaction she hadn't known two months ago she could afford.

Marius began to appear at the edges of her days like a drawing that water hadn't washed away. He raked the courtyard with a meticulousness that turned the long strips of fallen plane-tree bark into sentences. He replaced the hinges on the shed door and sanded them lightly, the sound like a cricket that had finally learned to speak softly. He asked her twice to show him how to twist the wire for a certain kind of petal, then left without a word when she fumbled and laughed at herself. He leaned against the gate one late afternoon and told her, in his flat voice that made all experiences sound equal, that the priest had gotten the story of his mother's birthdate wrong twice and that the knitted socks had been too tight on her feet in the casket, and that he had loosened them and felt a shame he did not recognize. Ileana listened the way she had listened to her grandmother when the stories were in danger of ending not with a moral but with a mistake. She did not apologize for the universe. She offered him a piece of sugar and watched him put it in his mouth as if it were medicine.

The building association, terrified of the momentum created by small groups of people who had felt something together, called another meeting. Cătălin came with a new stack of proposals: a painting of a parking lot so sleek it looked like a bathroom. He had switched products on them and now sold efficiency dressed as progress. "Trees," he said, with the patronizing tone he believed made him intelligible, "harbor insects. Children are bitten. People have allergies. We have to consider the quality of life."

"You don't get to define life for us," an old woman said from the back, and the voice was so fierce that everyone turned. She was bent, a little, like someone's prized birch. Her hair was the white of a noise that makes you fall asleep. "I have lived with insects and without. I prefer with. At least they mind their business."

"I can find a compromise," Ileana said, because she had not let go of the idea that a clever document might save a tree. "We can cut what is sick. We can plant under the windows that have mold. We can…" She saw Marius watching the top of the nearest pine as if it were a radio station in a storm. She saw him not speaking because he was saving the words for when the words had the right value.

"We can wait," Marius said, finally. He did not raise his voice. He did not move. "Wind comes. It tells you which branches want to break. We cut those, and only those. You do not pave over wind. It refuses. It comes back through the cracks."

The silence that followed sounded, in Ileana's ear, like a kennel full of dogs who had decided to obey. They voted, again, to revisit, again, which meant some trees would live by default. It was not victory. It was, in its way, better—life persisting through neglect as it always had in cities where people had more pressing things to break.

On a Saturday when the clouds lay like a stubborn duvet and the Dâmbovița had exactly the right amount of shine, she met Luminita and two women from the class in the community room and tried something new. Not only flowers. Birds. They cut paper so thin it was like the skin that forms on milk left too long on stovetops. They folded wings and creased beaks and made eyes with the blunt end of a toothpick. In her hand a white bird became a place where you might hang a wish without making a fool of yourself. They strung them with invisible thread, and for an hour the room looked like a chapel of truce.

"These," Luminita said, tying a knot so expertly that it disappeared, "people will call ridiculous. Then they will ask for ten. Then they will pretend they invented them. That's the progression. Try to be amused."

"I was born amused," Ileana said. "And tired of my own amusement. I want to see if I can ride it like a horse instead of being dragged by it. Does that make sense? No. Ignore me. Tell me which scissors cut without tearing."

"Those," Luminita said, pointing, and then, after a pause, "and also the ones you keep hidden for your own work. You are ready to keep some things."

The apothecary woman, whose name Ileana still hadn't earned, caught her on the way home and thrust a small jar into her hands. "Honey with propolis," she said, forestalling argument. "For the old ones with coughs that don't intend to leave until the first snow surprises them. Give it to the man with the cap. He pretends he won't accept charity. You do not offer charity. You offer a trade. He gives you stories for your bottles."

"I can pay—" Ileana began, and the woman shook her head in a way that looked practiced for decades.

"You will," she said. "By coming back and buying something you do not need, which is the definition of culture. Enough talk. The city is listening."

That evening, Marius stood with his hands in his jacket pockets and looked at the sky as if it were someone speaking a dialect he had only recently learned to love. She handed him the jar and told him there was medicine in it and also bees. He smiled with the edges of his mouth and no one else would have noticed. "My mother," he said, "used to give me honey in tea and call it a contract. If I drank, I had to sleep. If I slept, I had to be good the next day. If I was good, she would forget to pick up the belt. I will honor old contracts."

They sat on the bench while the dog attempted to dig a hole in a piece of ground that had no interest in being excavated. A woman in a velvet tracksuit walked by with a bouquet of supermarket chrysanthemums and said, with an odd generosity that carried no request inside it, "Beautiful. Paper?" Ileana said yes and did not explain herself, and the woman nodded as if it were as reasonable to make flowers as to wear velvet in June. Far away, a kid kicked a ball against a wall and learned something about force and the limits of it. Somewhere closer, someone practiced a trumpet badly and then correctly and then badly again, and the sound leapt across the air like a bright fish.

Sunday came with the taste of obligation. Her mother called early. "I heard about the mother of that man," she said, wasting no time on salutation. "The one with the keys. The one who sleeps with his broom. Dumnezeu s-o ierte. Did you go? Did you bring something? Did you embarrass us?"

"I brought coffee. Flowers. And myself," Ileana said, putting slices of peach into a bowl so carefully you would have thought an audience watched. "Mami, do you ever feel like the things you make with your hands are the only honest things you do?"

"I make sarmale," her mother said. "They do not lie. They either taste good or they don't. When your father died, the priest told me to knead dough until the salt came out of my eyes. I told him I would knead his head. Then I kneaded the dough. It helped and it didn't. Life is not a recipe. Why are you asking? Are you going to start making sarmale for money? The neighbor's daughter says that is a dignified profession."

"I am thinking," Ileana said, "of renting a small room. To hold classes. To sell what we make. To be poor in a different way."

"You will always be poor in one way or another," her mother said with that robust fatalism that had, over the years, produced both miracles and ulcers. "Better to choose the kind of poverty that suits your face. Call me when you need money. I will say no and then I will say yes and then I will tell you a story about when flour was rationed and I wore my cousin's shoes and my toe went blue."

After the call, she walked to a building three streets over, a former tailor's shop with windows that had traveled through three kinds of regime and could tell the differences if asked gently. The owner, a woman with sad eyebrows and an optimistic belt, showed her the space and waved her hand as if the air itself were rentable. "It's damp in winter," she said, because she was honest to a fault. "In summer the floor expands and pretends it's angry. The electricity is a religion we only believe in on Sundays. But look." She opened the back door, and a small courtyard revealed itself like a rabbit. A fig tree tried to be brave in a corner. "The light in the morning does something to paper. I don't know if that matters to you."

"It does," Ileana said, and saw, as clearly as she had seen an invoice the week the papers finally made sense, a class of women in cheap sandals and painted nails, a man with hands that shook folding a bird crease, a child who had wandered in trailing a sugar string, a jar with a label crooked, a box under the counter where she would keep money and secrets. She did not say yes, not because she was timid but because timing mattered. She asked for three days to think, and the owner said good, because people who say yes too quickly make expensive tenants.

On Monday, the city remembered to be cruel. A truck sideswiped a motorbike on Șoseaua Mihai Bravu and the ambulance took longer than anyone could bear; two men nearly fought outside the bakery because one had cut the line not out of arrogance but out of an emergency of digestion; Mara cried at her desk and said it was pollen and it was not. The jar with the white bells tipped and the bells stayed together, their wire doing what it was told. At lunch, Ileana signed her name to a transfer that made her stomach cold and her palms hot. She ate bread in the car with keys in her mouth and laughed, a little mad, at the absurdity of surviving via carbohydrates.

By evening, the wind had rolled a storm in under the balcony and set it down with a thump. She took the rosemary inside and set it next to the jar of paper and thought of ships coming into ports and being told to wait until the water was in a better mood. Marius knocked on her door, an act that made the air stand up. He held his cap in both hands as if it were something that might need soothing. "Tomorrow," he said, not stepping over the threshold, which thrilled and hurt her in equal measure, "we take the pom to the church. The boys asked if they could carry. I said yes if they wash and do not spit. You come?"

"Of course," she said, and then, because the whiteness of the day needed an anchor, "I found a place. Maybe. For classes. For… something we haven't named. Will you come see?"

"I will come stand at the door and pretend to guard," he said, and a corner of his mouth moved again. "And if anyone laughs…" He didn't finish. He didn't need to.

She thought, not for the first time that week, that perhaps love, in its early, almost invisible form, took the shape of apprenticeships you didn't agree to in words. She thought, also, that numbers would save her or comfort her or at least keep her honest. She wrote a list on the back of a receipt: rent, light, tape, wire, paper, chairs, tea, cups, a kettle that didn't flip its fuse like a teenager—then paused and added, in a hand that belonged to someone braver than she felt, the word enough. She pinned the receipt under a magnet that had come free in a magazine and that had long ago lost its picture but kept its hold.

When night fell, it was the kind that came down like a curtain, fast and unapologetic. The city sighed itself to sleep in dirty fits. In the apartment beneath hers, someone sang off-key for a minute; someone laughed; someone coughed; a baby failed to be consoled and then succeeded. The paper flowers on her desk threw faint shadows that looked, if you were inclined to superstition, like the writing of a language you hadn't yet learned but might, if you sat very still, someday read.

They carried the pom with the solemnity of boys pretending to be men. The youngest insisted on going in front, his hair smoothed with too much water, his shirt tucked with all the insistence of someone new to buttons; the tallest had a black ribbon pinned to his sleeve and a scab on his knee he thought no one could see. Marius walked beside them, one hand ready to catch if a wire slice wobbled, his cap tucked into the back pocket of his jacket as if he couldn’t bear to cover his head today. Ileana followed with the bag of candles and the matches and the sugar, the smell of beeswax and coffee leaking from the cloth like a confession. On the corner by the kiosk the woman who sold lottery tickets made the sign of the cross without interrupting her sales pitch; the bus driver waiting at the light nodded the slow nod men have for death that doesn’t belong to them but has walked their street before.

The church’s courtyard was freckled with gravel that pretended to keep shoes clean and failed. A black-coated man with a face like a thumbnail took the apples from the pom and wiped them on a rag that had wiped a hundred apples before; a girl in a pink hoodie asked the priest if she could ring the bell just once and the priest, after pretending to consider, let her tug the rope with two hands. Inside, the air folded around them the way it always did, incense and damp wood and old voices arranged like chairs. Women with scarves tied in knots at the top of their heads—old-fashion knots that said they did not care what magazines instructed—stood with their feet slightly apart, as if bracing for a wave. The candles took light obediently, and the honeyed smoke rose in ribbons that made the saints on the wall look like the people had brought them a weather report.

When the first prayer rose, low and droning, the boys fidgeted less. They had been instructed about biting their nails and not spitting, and they seemed glad that there was finally something for them to do that felt like a job: carry, stand straight, not drop. Marius stood close enough to the icon of the Mother that if he had leaned a fraction his cheek would have touched the frame; he did not lean. When the priest said Maria’s name, they said it back in a chorus that sounded like it came from a hundred throats and also from only one, and Ileana had that moment she always had in churches, the old surprise that so many separate bodies could produce one sound as if there were agreement in the universe about anything.

After the service, the courtyard woke into the business of grief. The coffee poured into plastic cups steamed like small grief-clouds; sugar cubes softened and broke in mouths that never mentioned sweetness on normal days. The pom stood by the gate, dressed with biscuits and coins, the paper bells pale in the bright. Children flowed around it with the instinctive respect children have for the things that might punish them; when the word came, like a small whistle of permission, they surged and plucked and fled with triumph that made the old women mutter a blessing disguised as condemnation. An old man unpinned a paper leaf and turned it in his fingers with the care he might have given to a photograph. “She would have liked this,” he said to no one, and the nod that came back belonged to three people and to the pigeons who had arrived to preside.

Marius took the jar of honey without theatrics. He held it in one hand and looked at it as if trying to recall where in the house he would put it so that it could be found by someone other than him. “She used to tell me the first spoon is the price you pay to be quiet,” he said, and tilted the jar to watch the slow adjust. “The second spoon is for promises. The third is for lying down.” He put the jar into the flat bag of grocery cloth with an efficiency that could have been mistaken for indifference. “You come tomorrow? The forty days. Don’t worry, we won’t make you stir the colivă. It must be someone with wrists like rope.”

“I can wash the cups,” Ileana said. “I can count the candles. I can take orders without thinking I have lost something by doing what I’m told.”

“Then you will be useful,” he said, and for the first time that day his mouth became a smile that showed itself and did not flinch away. “It is good to be useful when the world is trying so hard not to be.”

Back home, she didn’t go upstairs. The air under the plane trees felt like a waiting room with no clock. She sat on the bench and thought of the first time she had seen a pom, when she was five and her grandmother had insisted on pinning a coin to her dress because “the dead appreciate punctuality.” The pom had been beautiful in a way that frightened her then, all that order and white in a world that was otherwise goose feathers and spilled soup. She had assumed beauty was reserved for weddings, for people who had purchased permission. To see it surround a thing that was mostly absence had made her uneasy, and that unease had, it seemed, decided to live near her bones forever. She breathed, because Luminita had taught her to breathe in the stupid moments and the sacred ones, and the breath did what it always did: insisted she belonged in her body.

Upstairs, the notebook waited, and she opened it as if it might have grown teeth overnight. She wrote a list as a rehearsal in daring: call tailor’s shop owner about terms; ask Mara to design a flyer and pretend not to care if she groaned; buy a kettle, even if it explodes the fuse; find secondhand chairs, not too many, not too few; ask Luminita which days she’d teach if she were free of her stall in the afternoons; ask Marius if he would fix the hinge on the back door; ask the apothecary if she had a way to keep moths from eating paper that isn’t poisonous or a superstition that requires a hymn. The list looked like a benevolent threat. She understood that the only way to trick fear was to keep it so busy it forgot to show its teeth.

She signed the lease on a Tuesday at a desk that had seen uniforms and ribbons and ration cards and engagement party decorations. The owner wore her sad eyebrows and the optimistic belt and accepted a lesser deposit than she’d asked for without sighing. “I prefer occupiers of space,” she said, pushing the keys across the desk as if they were small children who must be taught to walk. “Empty rooms make a neighborhood ill. People start thinking the city is a hallway they can run down without hitting anyone. Bring tea. Put a curtain. Do not put fairy lights. My nerves cannot take them.”

“I will put a plant,” Ileana promised, and felt older and sillier for making a promise about a plant. She called Marius as she walked the three streets back with the keys, and the way he answered—one word—felt, by now, as intimate as any endearment she had received in her life. She told him the back door swelled in the frame; he grunted, which meant he would arrive with a plane and a small song he made with the blade without knowing. She told him the floor complained when she walked; he said he would bring wedges and the patience he usually reserved for the gate.

In the shop the light did its trick, slipping across the floorboards like a visitor who had been here before and was willing to pretend surprise. The walls had been papered and then stripped and then papered again, and they held, in abstract patterns, twenty years of someone else’s taste. The counter served no logical purpose yet, but she wiped it anyway, because wiping it gave it a function: to be cleaned, to receive palms, to brace a woman who might come in with a story. She stuck the kettle in the corner and ran a cord to an outlet that could not be trusted. She put the jar of honey on the shelf at eye level and permitted herself the superstition that it would sweeten something invisible.

When Luminita came, she brought the feeling she always brought, like a procession of good ants. Her bracelets chimed against the counter; her daughter-in-law carried a box of crepe like a baby. “We start with dust,” she announced cheerfully. “If you sweep before the priest comes, he scolds you for vanity. If you sweep before the city comes, it may give you a pass. Ah. Your windows will be your custom. People like to see their doubts reflected in pretty glass.”

“People like to see their reflections softened by something with a story,” Ileana said, and Luminita looked at her and grinned, a grin that included wrinkles that deserved their own church icon. “We will make a story. We will price it in coins and patience.”

Mara arrived late, carrying a plant she insisted was a fern and a poster she had designed on her lunch hour when she should have been filing invoices. The poster was black and white with one red flower, more motive than object, a corner accidentally torn because she had taken the tram at rush hour. “If anyone laughs at the font, we disinvite them from the human race,” she said, and then, seeing the keys on the counter, softened in a way she would deny if accused. “It smells like glue and ambition. Perfect.”

“It smells like the men’s barber used to smell,” said an old woman who had lived on the street since long before anyone started talking about property. She leaned in the door with her shopping bag resting on her shin. “Lemn. Marfă bună. Good wood. I had my hair set here once, when I could afford to be frivolous and not call it therapy. Are those paper? They look like what my mother made for the icon corner. She used to pin coins at the edge and tell us not to steal them unless we had a truly good plan.”

“You can come in,” Ileana said, gesturing her closer. “We have no prices yet, so everything is a gift or a mistake.”

“Gift,” the woman said, practical, and stepped inside, rubbing one thumb over another the way people do when they’re rehearsing a bill. “My niece is getting married for the second time, which is the time when people whisper louder. I intend to give her something that makes even ugly mouths close.”

They worked until the walls felt less like witnesses and more like accomplices. Marius planed the door and whistled without realizing it. He put a new screw in the hinge and told her to rub soap on the edge when it swelled in rain; he wedged the floor where the boards had started to believe in their own drama. He refused a glass of tea and then accepted it without thanks in the way of men who don’t know how to say yes without becoming susceptible to yes. When the first pair of teenage girls slipped in, open-mouthed and tenderly scornful of everything on principle, he pretended he had become a coat rack and let them compare strands of crepe to their nails under their breath. Young men walked by outside with the particular swagger of men who have seen something bad and decided to make it into a joke before it eats them; one stopped and said, “Bună, doamnă, how much for that, to take to a girl who will say no?” and Ileana named a price that made him blink and then grin and dig in his pocket as if the coins had decided, finally, to be brave.

Cătălin came, of course, as all people who imagine themselves center of a neighborhood come when they sense something is being built without their opining. He stood in the doorway with his arms crossed to reproduce the shape of a judge and said, “So. Arts and crafts. I suppose this is… charming.” It was the way he stretched the last word that invited blood. Marius didn’t change position. He wiped the blade of the plane as if it had been used to carve something important. “We’re building a place where people can hold something in their hands and not harm themselves,” he said, and the simplicity of the sentence did what long arguments couldn’t. Cătălin shrugged, made a comment about parking, and retreated into the world where he did not have to invent new ways to respect the work of others.

The first class in the new space was full because there are, always, people hungry for the kind of attention that has nothing to do with pity. A nurse came who had been told by her supervisor that her empathy was causing delays; a woman whose daughter had just emigrated to Germany and who wanted to make something that didn’t require visas; a boy with a shaved head and a scar near his ear who said his aunt had sent him and who spent the first ten minutes scoffing and the next forty watching his own hands with interest he tried to convert into disdain and failed; the man with the tremor returned and took his place in the corner by the window and whispered, as if to the scissors, “Nu te grăbi. Don’t rush.” They cut petals for chrysanthemums, the flower the city had decided could be all purposes if you were clever enough. Luminita made rounds like a ship’s captain; Ileana moved from hand to hand with tape and encouragement and the particular delight that comes from seeing a woman lift her head as if air has improved.

In between teaching and taping, in the hours where no one watched over her shoulder, Ileana ran numbers with the same reverence she ran her fingers over the good crepe. Rent and light and tape went into columns that did not shiver; the frog-march of expenses lined up; profit failed to appear in the cheeks as often as she liked, but it arrived in places she had not thought to count: in the woman who ignored the pain in her wrist for fifteen minutes because her flower needed one more turn; in the boy who carried a bouquet to the tram with the seriousness of a man who has decided to choose something for his life and is going to defend it; in the old woman who brought a jar of pickles and announced that everything good begins with vinegar and sugar in equal amounts. Mara stuck a small box by the door for contributions and closed her eyes when people dropped coins in it, because she believed money made fools of the generous and the desperate equally.

The apothecary woman came one afternoon wearing a cardigan that had seen three wars and a pair of shoes that promised nothing. She stood with her hands in the safe place that is the waistband of a skirt and watched without granting approval. When they paused, she said, “I am Viorica. If you insist on calling me doamnă, I will throw this jar of cucumber water at your feet and make you clean it.” The naming felt like a benediction and a dare. She set a small bottle on the counter—the kind with the dropper—and said, “Not homeopathy. Tincture. Real plant. Real burn. For the women whose sleep is not where they left it. I will charge you enough to respect it and not enough to resent me. And when the stubborn ones come—there are always stubborn ones who think will is stronger than chemistry—you send them to me and I will insult them into drinking tea.”

“Deal,” Ileana said, glad to be instructed. “And for moths?”

“Lavender,” Viorica said, rolling her eyes at the banality of it. “And cedar shavings. And a story stuck under the paper about a woman who kept a dress for twenty years because she thought she would be thin again and then wore it to visit the doctor who told her that thinness is a religion invented by people who don’t have to lift sacks of potatoes. Moths appreciate irony. They will go eat someone’s winter sofa instead.”

When the storm finally did what it had been rattling its chains to do for days, it threw a branch from the plane tree down like a sentence. The crack woke the courtyard. Cătălin took the branch in hand like an exhibit and said, “See? Danger. Lawsuit.” Ileana was at the sink, rinsing glue from her fingers, and when she came out, the courtyard had the particular charge it gets when men are ready to speak the way they think men should speak. Marius stood with his hand on the trunk, palm flat, like a doctor listening to a heart. “Only this one,” he said, tapping a higher branch with the metal tip of his broom as if the broom were a scalpel. “And the one behind it. The wind says these are bouncers. The rest can stand. They know how to bow.” He had a rope over his shoulder, a rope that had hauled fridges and sofas and once, he’d told her, a goat that had refused to negotiate with gravity.

“Call a company,” Cătălin demanded, waving his printed estimate like a flag. “Professionals. Insurance. Receipts.”

“This is a profession,” Marius said, tying the rope around the trunk without looking. “The wind and I will sign your receipt.” The little boys clustered, lip-chewing, feigning boredom with their hands in their pockets. Ileana had already grabbed the extra coil and fed him slack as he climbed, the rope braced across her waist, her heels dug into the courtyard’s reliable grit. The dog lay down with his nose on his paws, every nerve taut and pretending not to be. The climb was slow, the small movements of a man who had learned that heroism is another word for foolishness if you don’t watch the hinge. He looped the rope and cut with a saw that looked too modest to win and coaxed the branch down in a patient arc so that it landed as if choosing to lie. The second branch came easier; the third, once he was up there, Marius cut because it whispered so obviously of future disaster even Cătălin quieted. When he came down he sat on the trunk as if on an old friend and breathed as if he’d been holding the breath for an hour, which he had.

“You’re going to get yourself killed,” Mara said from the doorway of the shop, though her hands shook in the way of admiration looked at sideways. “And then who will I mock when my jokes land and need a soft place?”

“One day,” he said, wiping a scuffed hand across his face, leaving a clean print in the dust, “we will all be this tree. Someone will decide we are good for shade and also for accidents. If we are lucky, a person who listens to wind will make the call.” He nodded at Ileana, formal as if they were exchanging a medal. “You held well.”

“I count for a living,” she said. “I can count rope.”

Her mother came to the shop two weeks later, with the gait of a person who had resisted and then, against her own doctrine, given in. She wore her good coat because she did not believe in mixing sorrows and pleasures, and because if anyone photographed her she wanted to be able to show that she had always been dignified. She walked around like a border guard and then took a seat without permission at the corner table, where the papers slid into her possession. “Hm,” she said, about everything that might have elicited delight or disdain. “At least it is clean. At least you are not selling cigarettes to children. At least I can tell people you opened something and they will not imagine a mistake with a man.”

“Mami,” Ileana said, cutting a strip and then handing the scissors over, not because her mother had asked but because leaving her hands empty seemed unreasonable, “do you want to try?”

“I am not twelve,” her mother said, and then, two minutes later, holding a petal that had the shape of her own mouth, “How much do you charge for this? Huh. Too little. People think things are cheap when they are cheap. You must charge enough that they feel they have been forgiven for not doing it themselves.”

“So you approve?” Ileana asked, not because she needed permission but because the old instinct has a long leash. Her mother pursed her lips like a woman swallowing vinegar in order to feel superior to those who use sugar. “I approve of a woman who doesn’t wait for a man to bring her a violet,” she said. “And if you marry a fool, at least when he leaves you will have a room with keys. Did you put rosemary at the door? My mother did. It keeps thieves and melancholy away in equal measure.”

“I put rosemary everywhere,” Ileana said, and when her mother turned the petal between fingers thickened by decades of dough and buckets and lifting another life’s weight, something in the air settled as if furniture had been moved and finally found its right place.

Theft came anyway, because the city cannot resist a window. Two days after the class where they had learned to fold birds until the air looked like it believed in itself, a bouquet disappeared from the front display while she unwrapped a delivery in the back and Luminita was explaining to a man that no, his wife would not like orange lilies if she had said she did not. Ileana stood with the absence in her hand and felt, not anger, but a rush of pride that embarrassed her. “Someone chose us,” she said, and Marius, adjusting the sign that squeaked when the chock moved, nodded as if he had been waiting for her to understand the law of small losses.

“People steal what whispers to them,” he said. “They don’t bother with things that shout.” He looked toward the street where a woman in a blue dress with a fraying hem walked by, the bouquet tucked under her elbow like a loaf. “Maybe she is going to make trouble and needs courage. Maybe she saw her own hunger in your window and preferred to put it under her arm than admit it. If you like, I will pretend to chase her and scare her into buying two next time.”

“Pretend,” Ileana said, laughing into the tightness in her chest. “I do not want paperwork.”

By the end of the month, the shop looked as if it had always been itself. The good scissors had found their place under an old tin with a picture of peaches that were more fanciful than peaches ever are; the kettle had learned not to sulk when asked to boil; the corner where the floor pitched had become the province of children who preferred to sit on a cushion and cut badly until suddenly they cut well; the shelf near the window held bottles with labels written by a woman with handwriting that could convince goats to behave. People came and stayed beyond the time rational people allot for errands. They told Luminita about their exes. They told Viorica about their kidneys. They told Marius about their gates. They told Ileana about their daughters and their sons and their desire to stay in a city that had always made leaving sound so reasonable.

One evening, as the light made its little play on the wall, she counted taxis at the crosswalk not because the numbers would save her but because they were another way to keep time that didn’t involve waiting for emails. Seven stopped. Twelve did not. A man ran, his bag slapping his thigh, and made it, and lifted his hand to the driver as if to say, you saved my life. A woman refused to run, stood, let her hair lift in the small wind the cars made, and when a taxi did stop she shook her head, refusing the victory, and a small boy laughed, the delighted laugh of someone who has not yet learned that refusal is an art.
