She turned back to the table and pressed the edges of a peony between her fingers and knew, with the calm that arrives like a sleep when you stop insisting on it, that she had made a home out of paper that would not betray her as quickly as people did.

At night, when she closed the shutters and pushed the bolt and left the room to the dust that performs its slow arithmetic without witnesses, she walked home the long way, along the Dâmbovița that had decided, this late, to reflect faithfully. The river held, in streaks, the streetlamps and the absurd glow of a billboard promising eternal youth if you are willing to pay enough and a neon cross that blinked as if God had a sense of humor. She thought of the first time she had inhaled the smell of crepe dye and dust and felt something rearrange inside her like furniture moved in heavy rain. She thought of Marius’s mother, who would have laughed at the honey and told her not to forget to buy matches in case the electricity remembered its grudges. She thought of the way the boys had held the pom as if it were a person who needed convincing. She thought of Sorin, whose cologne had finally left the room, and of the way signing a name can feel like either murder or baptism depending on the ink. She thought of lists and felt no itch to write one.

At the bench, the stray dog lifted his head and watched her pass as if she were the moon and he didn’t want to miss the only show he could afford. The gate breathed when she opened it, no longer moaning, only informing the air. In the stairwell, someone had hung a sprig of basil because the neighbor’s baby had cut a tooth, and the smell felt like medicine trying to pretend it was celebration. On her table, the white birds hung from a wire like a small weather. They cast shadows that were not words yet and that might not become words and that, even so, taught her the patience to wait for a language that would take her, when it was ready, into its mouth.

By the time the ginkgo leaves remembered yellow, the Dâmbovița had a way of refusing to commit to any one temperament. It woke cold, chiseled by a breeze that smelled of rust and walnuts, then flared to life at noon when light poured itself in like uninvited relatives, and by dusk it had the sullenness of a child denied a fairground ride. Ileana watched it while counting taxis with the same cool attention she gave the spreadsheet column that always tried to frighten her. Four stopped; eight did not; one slid past, saw his own face in the glass of a storefront, and reversed sheepishly as if to apologize to his better nature. She sipped coffee and thought that perhaps it was good training, to keep track of small compliance in a city that rarely offered any, and then she put the mug down and made her morning list longer than it needed to be because she had learned that some days only obeyed if you gave them too many instructions.

The shop had learned its sounds. The front bell clicked instead of ringing, a modest scrape that let her keep talking without apologizing to the air; the kettle took three tries unless you muttered at it; the scissors made two notes, one when they opened and one when they submitted to what paper wanted, and there were customers who had begun to come not only for flowers but also for that music. On a Tuesday that was bright like clean plates, a woman wearing a hospital badge came in with her shoulders squared in a way that meant she believed in her work and had an equal affection for protocols. She looked at the white lilies with a face trained not to show longing and asked, nothing apologetic in it, whether paper made people feel foolish, because she wanted to put something in rooms where flowers made sick men sneeze and where daughters needed to know that beauty could be permitted to linger.

“They don’t die,” Ileana said, hating the sentence as soon as she heard it, because nothing that mattered had the decency to obey that particular law. She softened it with her hands. “They hold their shape when you ask them to. We can make them wrong on purpose, so they look less like the thing that makes people think of funerals. We can make them brazen. We can make birds, if birds feel easier. Tell me your rooms. I can picture them better if I know which window catches for no good reason.”

“The palliative ward,” the woman said, and then, because naming it out loud deserved a counterweight, she smiled and added, “The windows all catch. We keep a butter knife on a string to pry them. We keep it like an heirloom. They’ll call it kitsch, the old ones. They will call it kitsch until they see that it keeps shape when they forget to look. I can spend this much. If you throw in two extra because I lied and told you I can only spend this much, we will be friends forever.”

“Friends forever is expensive,” Ileana said, and Luminita, behind her at the back table, laughed the generous laugh that had first undone a morning at Obor and turned it into a promise. They made lilies that refused to behave, then taught them manners, and when the woman left with a box that knocked softly against her leg, the shop felt as if it had been entrusted with a seriousness it wanted.

The call from Constanța came in the hour of the afternoon when the light loses interest and papers become a duty rather than a reward. The driver breathed into the phone in that way people do when they have bad news to deliver to someone who is not their enemy. “Doamnă,” he said, using the formality as a life raft, “bleah, vameșii, the customs, they want a paper I do not have, which is to say they want money I pretend we do not carry. The container sits. The crane looks at me like a god. You come? Or you bless? I can wait two days before the warehouse man begins to explain patience to me with his elbow.”

She had learned to keep certain shoes under the counter for moments like this. She told Mara to hand Viorica the key if she came, to tell Marius where the ladder was if the back door sulked, and she kissed the top of the kettle as if asking it to behave in her absence. On the train, she stood because everyone stood, men pretending not to see her while also moving to give her space in that peculiar choreography of care Bucharest men performed when no one was watching, and she watched the fields scroll by, their green licked brown at the edges, hay rolls thrown like punctuation across flat sentences. She had forgotten the smell of the sea that’s not the sea but the port telling you stories about it; in her head, Constanța’s cranes were birds with good posture and mean tempers, its stacks of containers were books no one read but everyone quoted, and when she got off and the wind shouldered her, the salt was not romance but the metal kind that leaves its taste on the backs of your teeth.

At the gate, a man with a clipboard and a hairline that had negotiated terms with his skull looked over her head and past her shoulder and then finally, grudgingly, at her face. “If you are here to cry,” he said, not unkindly, “do it on that side. It’s the crying side. If you are here to argue, you need this badge. If you are here to bribe, use small bills. They disrespect big ones, think you’re showing off. Who are you? Don’t answer. I know who you are. You are the woman who refused to pay last time and made me find the paper that should have existed all along.”

“I am the woman who reads footnotes,” Ileana said, and he snorted the snort of a man who had once had dreams and now preferred efficiencies. There was an inspector who said the word “protocol” like a hymn, there was a worker who had learned to smoke with his lip instead of his fingers to keep both hands on what mattered, there was an office that had not changed since a government that no longer existed and would not change under three more. The paper they wanted did exist, but not in the way they wanted it, and she called the woman in a different office who owed her nothing and asked anyway, and the woman looked up the regulation and said, “If you promise to stop sending me emails at midnight, I will fax you the world,” and Ileana said “I do not promise,” and the woman faxed her the world anyway because sometimes refusing to be charmed is also a way of being charmed.

She did not pay. She paid in time, which is also currency, and she earned the container back with the kind of sweat that leaves no stain and that no one in the room will later admit to having noticed. The driver hugged her with his shoulder and said a blessing layered with cursing so that the gods would be amused and not take offense, and she stood there a minute and watched the cranes lower and raise their steel necks like pious dinosaurs and thought: this, too, is breath. She sat in a cafe near the port where the cups were chipped and a television in the corner pretended to be essential and counted, for her own stubborn reasons, how many men dipped sugar directly into their mouths before letting the coffee try its luck.

Back at the shop, the floorboards had survived a small flood, because Marius had heard, through the thin rattle of the radio and the fatter rattle of his own thoughts, a hiss behind the wall, and had pried the panel with a neatness that insulted nails. He had cut off the water with that calm anger that belongs to men who have repaired things in silence their entire lives, and when she returned with salt on her clothes, he pointed with his chin at the bucket and at the place where the floor had been lifted and then put back down as gently as a sleeping child. “It tried to remember it was a boat,” he said, and she laughed because she was tired enough to be obedient to good metaphors. “I told it no. I told it to be a floor. You owe me a rope. And a sandwich.”

“I owe you three ropes,” she said, thinking of the tree and of the way his breath had come down his throat like a saw’s tooth, “and an entire city that learns to mind its hinges when you ask it to.”

The boys had been to the shop while she was gone and had pressed their noses to the glass and written names into the steam and then wiped them away quickly because they had begun to understand that the pleasure of naming is sometimes in the privacy. One of them had slipped a paper bird into his jacket and then returned an hour later with his aunt and a folded bill and a face that tried to look like it belonged to a man who considered options. “It flew,” he said, irritated that anyone might find him remarkable. “Then it fell. It needs a perch.” He helped her tie a clear thread to the lamp and tried not to be proud when the bird did what gravity instructed in a way that made it look like hovering. Marius watched from the door and said nothing, reserving the simple sentence for later when the boy kicked the ball against the wall harder than necessary, and then he turned, fixed the latch with two small turns of his wrist, and told the boy, “Wanting is not shameful. Even for men. The trick is to learn where to put it.”

There were days when Viorica refused to be politic. A man marched into the shop with his chest ahead of his thoughts and demanded pills because his wife would not sleep and believed in drops more than in tea. Viorica stood with her cardigan buttoned up to the throat and her eyes two slits of patience and said, “Sir, if I sell you placebos, you will come back tomorrow and buy a more expensive lie. If I sell you sunătoare and tei and teach you where to put it in the cup and when to insist on quiet in your house, you will come back next week and pretend it was your idea and I will let you. Which do you prefer? I am cheap only in insults.” He bought both, of course, a vial to hide and a paper bag to show, and Ileana learned again that commerce, in its noble form, is partly theater.

The building association attempted one more coup, a meeting called under the pretext of “sanitation” where a man with a relative in a paving company unveiled a brochure with pictures of German courtyards pretending to be Romanian. There was so much glass that even the pictures looked cold. Ileana brought a jar of rosemary cuttings to the table like an offering and said nothing for ten minutes, letting the men tire themselves, and then she said, when the complications had been made to sound like inevitabilities, “If you pave this, heat collects. Children fall and their teeth chip. You will become the man who explains to a mother why her little boy’s mouth learned to be less lovely because your cousin sells stones. Do you want to be that man? Or do you want to be the one who can name three birds?” She did not mean it to be a charm. It worked as one anyway, because the old woman with the white hair who had won the last argument for them said, “Ciocârlie, mierlă, coțofană,” with relish, and Marius pointed at the plane tree and said, “And the wind,” and the paving company brochure, for once in its life, did not convince.

The forty days collected themselves like strict beads. The coffee diminished, the towels got washed and returned, the basil at the door of the apartment upstairs went from crisp to tired to brown and then bright again because a clever neighbor coaxed it back. On the fortieth, Marius stood like a guard and then like a son and then like a man who will have to decide how to talk about his mother when no priest is handy, and after the small procession, after the candles and the small rush of children’s hands, after the words that always came too late to be useful, he and Ileana walked, not together but in concert, toward the cemetery where Bucharest becomes quiet not out of respect but out of exhaustion. The path laced itself with old names and proud ones and ones written by a hand that hadn’t been taught to flourish, and every fifth grave had a plastic flower that had dimmed to a color not in nature, and Ileana put the white bird she had tied with thread on the corner of the stone and did not take a photograph because some things want to be proof only for the people who were there.

“How did you get that?” she asked him finally, when the silence had grown comfortable enough to hold a story without dropping it, touching her wrist in the same place his scar made lace. He looked at his own, turned it, judged it as if he were appraising a tool at the market. “A belt caught my hand at the factory when I was nineteen and thought I was invincible, which is to say stupid,” he said, in that flat tone that refused pity on entry. “It sent me home for three weeks to learn that I liked the way the courtyard smells after rain more than I liked men yelling at me to hurry with bolts. I went back because you go back. The second time I left because my mother fell, and then I did not go back because things needed fixing closer to our door. I became the man who knows doors. It is not a profession. It pays me in the absence of fire. I do not hate it.”

“I make order out of paper,” she said, like a confession and like a joke, and he nodded because for once the sentence did not need to learn irony to live.

The newspaper discovered the shop the way newspapers discover things that have been waiting like small friendly traps for years. It sent a woman with a notebook who tried to be invisible and then gave up and asked questions and then stopped asking and cut a petal and taped it badly and decided not to be embarrassed by being taught. The headline, when it came, made her choke on her toast: “For the Living and the Dead: A Shop Where Paper Holds.” There was a photograph where her hand looked more confident than her face, there was a paragraph that convinced even Cătălin to stop saying “crafts” as if he were allergic, there was a sentence that made her mother phone and say, “You look tired but important,” which was the closest thing to unambiguous praise the woman had in her pantry. Sorin sent a message with no letters, only a half-smile and a question mark, and she moved the message into the folder where she stored other things she refused to feed.

The hospital ward made its own kind of weather. The lilies sat on the windowsill like brave soldiers. A woman whose granddaughter had braided blue into her hair the day before said, “They will not die on me,” and picked one up and examined it like a problem she could finally solve. A man with fingers that trembled less when he held wire asked if he could keep the bell until the nurse told him he couldn’t, and the nurse did not. At night, when Ileana lay down, she could see where the paper’s grain had given a petal a line like a life line in a palm, and it pleased her in a way she did not try to explain to herself.

There was theft, again, delightfully. A bouquet went, a small one, the kind that sits in the bend of an elbow on the way to an apology. Ileana lifted the absence in her hand and felt the flare of anger the city teaches you to keep ready, and then she put it down and let the pride replace it, because she had decided that pride, in reasonable doses, kept a woman from shrinking for no pay. Marius made a show of checking the screws on the display and said, as if instructing her in a recipe, that if you arrange the stems with the cut side toward the door the petty thieves might hesitate because they fear sap, even if there is none. “People who take without asking,” he said, “are often idioti with manners toward plants.”

The tailor’s shop became, in the fastest way a room can, a place people started giving addresses with when they wanted a friend to know they were paying attention. “At the paper,” they said, and meant the corner with the strange light and the woman who tried not to boss you unless her eyebrows lost patience. Viorica started to leave her bottles in a row that made an army of browns; she behaved as if she had always kept office hours there and then scolded a teenager into eating soup with garlic when he confessed he hadn’t breathed through his nose in a week. Luminita, who had taught her bracelets to learn a softer chime in small rooms, started a class made only of people who claimed they did not need companionship and then claimed it anyway. Mara kept a list of the worst fonts people suggested for their poster, and when the list reached ten, she bought a pastry and said she would forgive the city anything for sugar.

One afternoon, the light decided to show off. It came through the old glass and fractured itself on dust and hung in the air as if it had come to class late and wanted to demonstrate that it could still answer questions. Ileana took down the white birds and dusted the thread with the careful pinch of someone who knows how little frays matter until they suddenly do, and she thought of the first day she had met Luminita and touched crepe without believing in her own fingers, and of the way she had said no to the easy money and yes to the thing with no guarantee, and of the way a man like Marius could hold a rope and tell a branch when to surrender. She wondered if everything she loved now was a way of convincing herself that control existed, even in small clever forms, even in rooms that leak, even in courtyards where men vote on light, and the thought did not shame her. There are worse religions than faith in a hinge that obeys oil.

In the evening, the Dâmbovița did that trick it had not tired of, holding on its back the entire neighborhood in pieces: a window with a woman’s hair in it, a neon pharmacy cross that blinked as if to keep time for ambulances, a lamp that made old paint on a bridge look like a blessing. The wind had learned everyone’s names by now, or at least their whistles; it slipped between buildings the way people slip into rooms where they’re not expected but know they’ll be tolerated. Ileana walked slower than she had when the shop was an idea that pinched; she could afford to take time from herself and hand it back. The bench in the courtyard was free for the first time all afternoon, the dog having decided to inspect a more promising smell near the bins, and she sat and counted not taxis but windows that let their curtains be open, and the number surprised her. She had always imagined the city closed against itself; she had been wrong in a way she could enjoy.

“Tomorrow,” Marius said from the shadow near the gate, not emerging as if to honor the old liturgy he had invented for them where their most important sentences lived near the edge of seeing, “we will take down the pom.” He had put off the act not because he was sentimental, which he distrusted in himself, but because he believed in certain arbitrary intervals. “Bring your scissors with the black handle. Not the ones your mother used. They bite.”

“I will bring the ones that forgive me when I pull wrong,” she said, and in the way the courtyard accepted the sentence and held it and then let it go, there was the smallest kind of peace. She wrote a list when she climbed the stairs, not because it would save her, but because it would remind the part of her that fussed that there were things she could do while the city made its ancient, ridiculous plans. Wire. Lavender. Receipt book. Rope. Kettle gaskets. A plant that is not rosemary, because we must not demand too much from one soldier. And at the very end, underlined because it had become a form of prayer: call Viorica; ask for a story to get us through winter.

They took down the pom in a morning that had the patience of a slow kettle. Light entered the courtyard as if someone had loosened a faucet, a trickle that dared not turn into a rush. The boys, who had carried it with such gravity weeks ago, had already begun to grow in the way boys do when grief makes them pretend to be furniture—useful, quiet, sturdy, a place for other people to put cups. Today they had the twitch in their legs again; they wanted tasks that felt like danger but could be disguised as duty. Marius brought out the old wooden ladder and leaned it into the tree’s shoulder as if it were leaning into a man who had promised not to move. Ileana stood with her black-handled scissors, not the ones her mother had used, and felt for the first time that the blades had moods. The paper was softer where fingers had touched it for weeks, oil turning crispness into a compliant satin. She cut the threads that held bells and leaves and biscuits, and each time a ribbon came loose and fell into her hand she thought of a sentence being unstitched quietly so that the meaning could be used again elsewhere.

They kept the coins for the church’s box not because anyone needed to be conscientious about accounting but because ritual pays its debts how it can. The apples had shriveled into smaller truths; the youngest boy bit into one, grimaced, and then finished it with the bravado of someone who had decided to be stubborn on principle. A neighbor who had mislaid her spectacles and found them on top of her head twice in the same hour stood to collect the paper bells with the kind of care that would have made you think they were porcelain. “For Easter,” she said, though no one asked her to justify herself, and then whispered to Ileana as if they were sharing contraband gossip, “I like it when things last too long and make people nervous.”

When the wire crown came off the top of the pom, Marius bent it back into a line with his palms, slow, as if he were listening for its permission to be straight again. His face was back to its practiced privacy, but his hands were less stingy. He passed Ileana the bent shape, and she coiled it like a snake that had remembered being a rope. “We make another,” he said, not to fill the air but because repetition had become a form of respect. “For someone we do not yet know. That is a good way to spend a day.”

After the pom, after the biscuits were redistributed and the stubborn apple core was thrown to the dog by a boy who pretended the dog’s delight was beneath his notice, the courtyard resumed its weekday argument with time. The building’s pipes shouted once and then held their peace. Somewhere an impatient shoe learned the rhythm of the stairwell. In the shop, the kettle did its old trick of sulking until talked to like a friend who might leave, then boiled as if it had never doubted itself. Luminita came late and apologetic, bracelets subdued, a new cut on her thumb that she waved away with the breezy contempt of a woman who has had worse. “My daughter-in-law says we should put our classes on Facebook,” she announced, as if they were considering inviting an ancient aunt to a party. “I told her Facebook is a square where everyone screams and counts that as conversation. She called me medieval. I told her I prefer ages where people look at you when they lie.”

“We can do both,” Mara called from the counter, where she had arranged small birds in a row to resemble a sentence only she could read. “The square and the room. One pays in clicks, the other pays in people. Both currencies are unreliable, but at least the people sometimes bring pickles.”

“Do not bait me with pickles,” Viorica said from the doorway, and dropped a bundle of dried lavender on the counter like an assignment. “For your moths. And for your nerves. A city is a mouth. It will chew you unless you make it bite something else. Today I bring a story about a woman who tried to heal a fever with brandy and then married the man who brought her water instead. It will get us through November.”

She told it while they cut paper to the width of a thumb. It was a shabby story at first, a story of a woman whose kitchen had a floor that sloped toward the door so that soup was obliged to learn maritime law, and of a doctor who had learned, young, that if you arrive with authority and a clean collar, people forgive you almost anything. The brandy was a neighbor’s prescription, the water was the doctor’s, and the temperature dropped because time did what it sometimes does when you are watching it too closely and decides you do not deserve a lesson you have paid for. “The woman married the doctor,” Viorica concluded, rolling a piece of green tape between her fingers until it warmed to her will, “and then spent forty years telling him that it had been the water. He let her have it, which is the only reason they lasted. Men are not saved by tinctures. They are saved by choosing which parts of the story to insist on.” She looked at Marius as if to make sure he had heard. He nodded gravely, which in his language was the same as a laugh.

When the weather lowered its chin and breathed chill, the shop filled with the kind of customers who had opinions about warmth. A woman with a small dog in her big bag demanded birds with gold edges for a chandelier because the electrician had told her she could not hang anything heavy with the way the ceiling had been compromised by a leak three tenants ago. “Gold,” she said, tapping her nail against the counter as if it were a snare drum. “But tasteful. I do not want my living room to look like a cake.” A man ordered paper poppies to lay at a monument and took offense when Luminita tried to steer him toward a red that wasn’t the exact red his grandfather had mouthed the word for. “The exact one,” he said, showing a photograph where the colors had been ruined by time into a truth of their own. “Our dead are particular. They do not forgive approximations.” They made the petals darker than any poppy would dare be in an obedient field, and he lifted the finished bouquet with hands that understood receiving instructions and not liking it.

With the cold came a new logistics problem, which was simply the old problem wearing a thicker coat. The container that had nearly been held in Constanța arrived wheezing, and the driver called from the hive of trucks near the ring road to say he’d be late because men in reflective vests had decided to argue philosophy with cones. Ileana learned the trick of telling a client that their order was en route in a tone that conceded nothing and apologized for nothing, and when Mara managed to talk a warehouse manager into staying open for an extra hour on the strength of a lie about frozen syrups, they sent each other a message with a single goat emoji and a time, their code for not being entirely defeated by the day. Sorin’s name stopped appearing in the inbox like a sting; when it popped up once, weeks after he had signed the paper that made him a figure in a story rather than a participant, it arrived with an invitation to a holiday party and a tone that imagined itself as magnanimity. She archived it without sentiment and went to check on the heater’s habit of sulking.

On a morning brittle with a frost that made even the loudest men adjust their voices, the hospital nurse returned to collect a second order. Her badge had slid on its string to the angle that nurses’ badges always adopt, the angle of someone who has brushed against too many tragedies in too narrow a hallway. “They said it was kitsch,” she admitted, holding the box as if it were a small animal that might startle easily, “and then one of the old men asked if he could take the lily with him when he was transferred, and the young doctor who thinks evidence is a religion said yes with his face and no with his mouth, and the old man found a way to take it anyway. It is sitting on his tray like a friend who has forgiven you for having been boring.” She paused and looked at Ileana with curiosity that had learned its manners. “Why paper for the dying?”

“Because the shape holds,” Ileana said, only a little rehearsed by now, because some thoughts become furniture and you learn to run your hand over them when you pass. “And because a fresh thing decays and reproaches you, and paper keeps its peace. It is not honest; I know. But existence allows cheats when the test is cruel.” She gave the nurse two extra bells because there are economies you can afford when your profit is not entirely counted in bills.

That same week, the building declared war on its own pipes. A banging began behind the wall like a neighbor practicing the drum without having first discovered rhythm; then came a hiss and then a thin jet of water that had no intention of negotiating. Marius appeared with his little army—the wrench that had belonged to another man’s grandfather, the roll of Teflon tape that resented hurry, the old cloths that had once been a good shirt—and shut off the right valve with the accuracy of a father reaching for a falling glass. He did not curse, which was how she knew it was bad. The downstairs neighbor, whose timeshare with rage had been generous and public, arrived at the shop door with a look that told them the city could be sued and would laugh. “It dripped on my bread,” he announced, all liturgy. “God will punish you. Or I will.”

“Bring the bread,” Viorica said from the counter, not looking up from a label she was writing that requested that people not take more than two droppers at once unless they wanted their stomachs to learn remarkable new tricks. “I will cut off the wet parts. You will eat. Then you will help carry the bucket. God punishes those who never bring the bucket.” The man looked prepared to be outraged and then, without fanfare, obeyed. Sometimes the pivot between fury and usefulness is only a sentence spoken in no one’s special language.

On a Thursday, with the window glass dull from the city’s breath, a woman came in with a veil that signaled loss but not how recently it had arrived. She had a small boy by the hand, the kind of boy who counted cracks in the floor and then tried to step on only the light ones. She looked at the white carnations and put her fingers to the base of her throat in the old gesture people make when their body wants to prove it’s still there. “My mother had these,” she said, the way someone says “That was my street,” not asking for ownership, only trying on the fit. “She said the paper forgave her for having to do this twice. I want a cluster. Not too neat. She was not neat. She was… generous. Generosity makes a mess.”

“Mess we can do,” Luminita said, and the way she scattered the petals looked like luck but was, of course, precision disguised. The boy squeezed the end of the green tape until it stuck to itself and then made a little sound of disapproval at his own error. Marius, who pretended not to know children unless they needed a bandage or a door closed, took the tape and reversed it neatly as if errors were a currency he liked to handle. “I wanted to bring real flowers,” the woman said as if confessing greed in a church. “My sister said they would be a waste. My aunt said paper is for brothels and parastase. I said, then let the brothels and parastase teach us how to keep color.”

“You will never go wrong listening to brothels and parastase,” Viorica remarked without a pause, and when the woman laughed, the room took that laugh and put it carefully on the shelf where they kept small, useful things.

The tailor’s shop next door let a rumor loose that warmed the street; there was to be a winter fair in the triangle where the tram turned and husbands leaned and watched their breath. It was a shabby sort of fair with a tent that smelled like soup, but there would be a stage and a man with an accordion who owed money to a woman who sold onions and there would be mulled wine in cups that would stain everyone’s mouths the same optimistic red. Mara volunteered their presence before asking, and Ileana said yes before counting because sometimes you must learn to throw yourself into a market and see who catches you. They prepared over-red roses that would laugh in the face of poinsettias, and birds with tails that flickered like small flames, and wreaths that would let a door pretend to be a gate into a more forgiving place.

On the day, the wind came and left like a lover with an appointment; it tugged hair and made the tent flap like a big mouth trying not to laugh. They arranged their table with the precision of people who were not going to be mocked today, not because they were fragile but because they had decided to refuse the effort of deflecting. Cătălin came by twice, the first time to remark that the table would do better closer to the stage, the second time to say a man he knew could get them real plastic flowers at such a price that they would think they’d robbed him. “We are committed to our ridiculousness,” Ileana said simply, and he nodded in the way men nod when they realize no amount of reason will dislodge someone’s pleasure.

The children loved the birds, to no one’s surprise. They tugged at the invisible thread and delighted in the way the body of the bird refused to be entirely obedient to gravity. A teenager with a face he’d practiced in the mirror bought a small violet because he had been told once that violet was the color of fidelity and he wanted, for once, to be on the right side of a symbol. An old man with hands like bark told them, as if they had asked, that his wife had made paper peonies for the baptisms of all three daughters and then stopped when one daughter decided to be done with the church and the other two moved away and forgot to ask permission to be happy. “I still have them,” he said, and the words carried the grain of both boast and mourning. “They are ugly with dust. They are also the most beautiful things I own.”

Late in the day, as the stage creaked under a group of boys with a hip-hop song they had written to insult each other lovingly, as Viorica argued bourbon versus rum in mulled wine with a woman whose apron had remembered every soup she had ever made, a woman with a microphone approached the table and asked if anyone would talk into the air about what, exactly, they were selling. “Order,” Mara said, without looking up, and the woman laughed until she realized the answer would not get better if she waited. Ileana said, because she had learned which sentences to reach for when the air asked, that they made flowers for the living rooms of people who could not be trusted to water a plant and also for the rooms where no one dared bring a bucket, that they made birds for windows that insisted on showing people the wrong scene, and that they made wreaths for doors that had learned to choose who to open for and who to leave on the landing. The woman wrote nothing down and thanked them and tried to summarize and failed, which pleased Ileana more than a clean paragraph would have.

When the fair ended and the men unhooked the tent from the sky and folded it badly, the street felt bigger for having been used without injury. They counted their coins not with a miser’s delight but to see if the city had given them its old yes. They had enough to pay for trays of cabbage rolls and extra glue and the bottle of brandy Viorica wanted to keep in the back for the kind of days that only yield to rituals older than science. Marius carried the crate back to the shop with one hand, the other hand in his pocket as if to telegraph that nothing on the street was a threat. When they reached the door, he said, half to himself, half to the hinge, that he could smell snow, and they all looked up like children promised a show.

Snow fell like someone had finally stopped asking the sky to be reasonable. It came in flakes fat enough to be counted and made the Dâmbovița look like an old woman’s shawl shaken from a chest. There is a particular hush that happens in Bucharest when snow decides to take its job seriously. For a few hours, even the men who insist on their car’s right to block the tram behave like citizens of a place that can be improved by silence. Ileana watched the river fold itself and then improvise again and counted the taxis that chose to stop because it felt stingy not to. She texted her mother to say “It snows” and her mother sent back a photo of a pot on the stove, the steam rising like a saint. The shop grew candlelight-fat; people came in to warm their hands and left with birds because birds looked good against winter. A young father bought a single white carnation because his daughter had said at breakfast that the weather made her heart feel like a fish in a jar and he had no idea what to do with such a sentence except take it seriously.

The cold brings with it a mean-spirited generosity: it clarifies. The building’s windows separated themselves into those that wept and those that held their ground; the gate told them exactly when it would stick and why, and Marius, who carried a crumb of graphite in his pocket like a talisman, drew a line where the metal lied about itself and shaved the lie off. He climbed the plane tree once to knock snow from branches that pretended they were stronger than they were, and when he came down with white pushed into the crook of his cap he looked younger and not at all absurd. He told the boys that snow was the only teacher who could make them quiet; they ignored the insult and built a fort that pretended to be a castle and learned, without admitting it, the sweetness of holding a line together.

In a pocket of afternoon when the light forgot to be brave, Viorica arrived with a jar of something that moved slowly. “Quince,” she declared, setting it down with the authority of an old cookbook, which is to say, godlike. “For irritating throats and nostalgia. Both respond to sugar cooked until it tells the truth.” She wore a knitted hat that made her look like a woman who did not tolerate cold if she could insult it into submission. “Tell me a problem,” she demanded, and when no one volunteered, she provided one. “I have a niece who reads on her phone until her eyes are the color of old bricks. She refuses to rest because her friends live in her palm. I will not sell her drops; I will sell her boredom. We will learn to sit and watch steam. It is not a modern cure. It is a good one.”

“Teach a class,” Ileana said, because the room had begun to feel eager for such sentences. “Not here. Here, the steam will carry the glue into our lungs and we will die of our own ambitions. In your shop. On days the wind is rude. Call it decanting. People will pretend to understand.”

“I refuse to teach,” Viorica said with relish. “I will host. I will let the jars speak for themselves. I have told them to behave in guests’ presence. They are well brought up.”

Toward the solstice, when the city eats sausages and waits for it all to be over, Sorin appeared in the shop, smelling like the part of winter that costs extra. He stood in the doorway like a man who has learned to make his silhouette into a signature and smiled in a way he thought charming when it had often, elsewhere, scored points. “So this is where you hide,” he said, looking past her with the cultivated interest of a collector who has stumbled on an object that might yet become a trend. “I read about it. I thought, surely not. But here you are, with, what do they call it, artisanal—”

“Flowers,” Ileana said, relieved at how easily her mouth refused to be managed. “They are not a concept. You can buy one if you intend to take it home and not put it on a conference room table as a conversation piece. If you are here to suggest painting the walls dark and installing a neon sign, I will ask Marius to escort you to the gate and instruct it to close.”

Sorin looked at Marius and calculated, for once honestly, and decided to become generous. He picked up a bird with careful fingers, the way men handle small things that might embarrass them, and tilted it so the light traced its back. “For my daughter,” he said, and she had forgotten for a moment that he contained people who did not smell like his cologne. “She has become a critic. She will tell me if it is sincere enough to be tolerated. She has learned this word at school: authentic. I cannot stand it, and I am grateful for it.” He put money on the counter and added more than was logical, and Mara started to mock him and then, seeing the way his eyes took stock of the corners as if he were finding a place where he might, in another life, have been useful, decided to be merciful. He left with the bird wrapped in paper that had once been a newspaper story about a politician who had since left the country, and for once the paper served a purpose beyond its assigned pretense.

On the last day of the year, when fireworks practice all afternoon like untrained brass, the courtyard produced its own rough pageantry. The old woman with the white hair brought a jar of compote she had saved for a moment when someone else’s mouth needed sweetness; the boys lit sparklers and discovered, to general relief, that they were not yet the kind of men who could be trusted with explosives; a teenager kissed another teenager with a bravery that made Marius find a hinge to fix intently; Viorica pretended to disdain the music that came from a neighbor’s radio and then hummed while she counted how many cups had gone missing as if each cup were a person who owed her a debt. At midnight, the Dâmbovița reflected the wild and bad decisions of the city with a stoic little shimmy. Ileana stood under the balcony and counted backwards because she liked the way numbers lined up when you granted them an ending. Seven, six, five, and she thought of the list she had written the day the ginkgo went yellow and how most of it had been done by hands other than hers and how this did not offend her at all.

She went to sleep with the noise lodged in the curtains and woke to a quiet that felt borrowed. In the blunt morning, she wrote in her notebook before coffee because she had learned not to trust herself to remember if she deferred. The list was short; it made her uneasy, as if a day with only four instructions might decide to go feral. She added small things—buy more tape, speak kindly to kettle, ask Marius his mother’s second favorite joke—and then put the notebook down as if it were a pet that had fallen asleep on her lap and didn’t mind being displaced.

In January, the river grew a small skin that broke when pigeons put their minds to it. The city pretended to be resigned and was, in fact, simply cold. The hospital called for more lilies, because the new doctor who measured his kindness in metastable doses had been converted by a woman who thanked the flowers instead of him, and his resistance to anything he could not measure had wilted in the face of gratitude that recognized allies. The tailor next door closed for two weeks because his daughter had given birth in Spain to a child who would learn to count in a language he would only love second-best, and the shop lended him its key so his son could come in and stand and pretend to be in charge of something while he figured out whether his ribs could carry pride.

There were bad days that bloomed without warning, as bad days always do. A man came in and insulted the price and the premise and left having given nothing and taken thirty minutes of their time and the energy that they could otherwise have used to be patient with themselves. A box of crepe arrived the wrong weight and the warehouse manager insisted the scales had been calibrated by God and she had to spend an afternoon proving that human hands cheat because life requires us to practice. A child tore a bird and cried, and his mother scolded him with her shame disguised as authority, and Luminita had to take them both in hand and declare that everyone was being ridiculous because paper is a thing that forgives even when people don’t.

On a day when the light did not rise beyond a reluctantly polite glow, a woman from a cultural institute came in with hair that had learned the hard way to be restrained. She wore a scarf that announced funding and asked, with the eagerness of someone who had been told to go find authenticity and could now bring it to a meeting, whether they would consider a workshop in a room with white walls and a video camera set like a trap. Ileana said yes because she wanted to watch people discover their hands in rooms where their voices had been trained to echo, and she said no to the part where the video clip would be cut with dramatic music because paper did not need violins to be understood. Mara designed a flyer with exactly the right amount of black and exactly the right weight of paper, and the institute woman cried at a petal because she had been forced, by her job, to become an expert at pretend.

The day after, when it seemed the city had gone back to biting itself out of habit, Marius knocked on Ileana’s door with a hammer tucked under his arm as if it were a polite dog. “You wrote,” he said, unembarrassed to have read her list where it lay on the counter near the kettle, “to ask my mother’s second joke. Her first was not for polite company. The second was that God made the wind and the priests take credit. It made her laugh alone in the kitchen. It will not sound funny if you say it at a party. That is good. Humor should be private.”

“I will tell it to the kettle,” she said. “It will boil from relief.” He leaned against the doorframe and looked at her rosemary as if it were an old friend who had learned to pretend to be new. “She would have liked this shop,” he added after a small silence in which the building considered whether to creak or keep its dignity. “Not because of the flowers. Because people come to be asked for nothing. She would have come and told Luminita she was making too much fringe and then told her a recipe and stolen a spoon. She would have argued with Viorica about licorice root until they fell into agreement out of exhaustion. She would have told you that the gate is your best advertisement, because it opens without complaining.”

“Then I am doing something right,” Ileana said, and though she knew better than to ask for approval from the dead, she felt the kind of measurable peace that the living can convert into work.

February tried to be cruel in new ways but found it had already used up its tricks. The boys discovered a new game with the rope and did not hang themselves with it. The building association tried one last resolution to pave the courtyard and lost not because anyone had made a speech but because half the people decided to make soup instead of attend. Sorin sent a postcard from somewhere warm with a photo of a fruit that looked indecent and wrote only “Courage,” which was a word he had never used when it had been needed. Viorica’s jar class became a rumor that made strangers knock and ask, cautiously, whether boredom was, in fact, for sale. Luminita announced that she would teach a session on funerary wreaths that did not insult the dead by pretending they were never rude, and the class filled with women who had learned to love without bleached corners.

On a morning that held itself upright like a conscientious chair, the apothecary’s bell rang before Viorica had turned her sign, and she barked at the door in a tone that would have made a general sit down. It was a woman with a hat like an apology, who explained in four sentences and a half-swallowed sob that her mother had died the previous night with a curse in her mouth and a request that made no sense. “She said,” the woman reported, wringing her hands not because it helped but because she needed to see they were still attached, “to bring her girls something that lasts and looks like a lie.” Viorica, who would insult men into health but never laughed at the confused request of a daughter, wrote a list that contained, among practicals—candles, coffee, sugar—only one instruction that mattered. “Go to the paper,” she said. “Ask for white that looks wrong. The dead, sometimes, appreciate our reluctance to be obedient.”

Ileana made a wreath with leaves that insisted on their grain and bells that did not line up on purpose. They tied a blue ribbon under the white because the woman’s hat had a single stitch of blue at the brim, and the effect pleased no one and satisfied the truth. When the woman took it, when her hands steadied for the span of two breaths, Ileana felt a fatigue lift off her shoulders like a coat. There are works that repay on delivery; this was one. She wanted to write it down—the exact angle of wrongness that works when grief is a poor audience—and knew that some things refused a ledger.

Toward the end of winter, the Dâmbovița began its lazy rehearsal for spring. Bottles that had frozen into small sculptures shivered themselves loose; gulls came back in committees and inspected their old arguments; a man washed a car with water from a bucket and made a mess of his ankles and did not mind. The rosemary by the window put out a sprig that looked greener than it had any right to be. The boys’ fort dissolved into reasonable piles. The gate’s hinge needed oil and got it. The shop learned the names of people’s grandchildren as if they were a currency required to be legal, and Luminita taught a class of teenagers to make peonies that would eventually, when photographed in a mirror, become declarations of someone’s new room. Marius repaired a hinge for an old woman who insisted on paying him in string and he accepted without altering his face, and on the way back he stopped at the bench and called the wind by its name in a voice too low for anyone but the plane tree to appreciate.

One evening, when the light had that thrift-store gold that makes everything look like a bargain, Ileana locked the shop, put the bottle of quince in her bag because it had promised to make a visit to her mother more palatable, and sat on the bench to count taxis not because she needed to but because repetition had become a hobby. Marius sat, not touching, and told her, quite simply and with his voice smaller than usual, that he had had a bad dream. It involved the factory belt and his mother and the gate refusing to open and the wind turning its back. He said it without drama, as if reporting a new sound in the pipes, and she listened in the same key. When he was done, he said, “I went downstairs and stood in the courtyard so it would be stupid to be afraid, and the dog put his nose in my hand like he was paying for something and then ran away. It helped. Or it did not. It is hard to say.”

“I will ask Viorica for a story,” she said. “Or for a bottle without a label. Sometimes labels make their contents shy.” He nodded and took the quince and said he would tell her if he hated it, because that would be a mercy, and she laughed, a small, exhausted, grateful laugh that made the evening tuck itself in.

Spring would find them. It would arrive not because they had arranged themselves worthily but because the city is generous with its cycles. For now, in a winter that had shown its teeth and then let them rest, they sat with their hands empty, not taking inventory, and watched the small movements—the river’s edge relearning the trick of ripple, the gate agreeing with its hinge, the boys stomping their boots to hear the hollow thud—that make a life you can bear to live.

By March the city remembered its old trick of tying red to white and pretending a thread could hold winter away. The first morning of Mărțișor, tram handles wore tiny tassels, and girls on the tram pretended not to notice who had pinned what to whose coat, and men with the practiced shame of tenderness fumbled in pockets for string like contraband. Obor was a rash of stalls that looked like someone had tipped a sewing basket over Bucharest; plastic clover and silver hearts and the small, miraculous women who made delicate knots with hands that had wrung laundry their whole lives argued for attention in a register that didn’t tax the ears. Luminita had decided, with the briskness of a woman who considered tradition another material to be cut, that paper could be a Mărțișor, too, and the first morning she had, pinned to a length of string on her table, tiny bells that were irreverent, a red peony no wider than a coin, a white bird that flinched at its own shadow and then held. “They will say it is too much,” she predicted, slicing the tramp’s red thread with scissors that looked like they might take offense at modernity, “and then their fingers will betray them. People buy excess in March because it is cheap forgiveness.”

Ileana bought too many, then talked her way out of shame by delivering half to the hospital nurse who had begun to use the shop as a place to breathe and to finish a thought. The nurse’s badge had learned to sit straight for a change; she pinned a paper bell to its corner and said, in the voice of a person who knew how to make bureaucracy obey desire for ten seconds at a time, that the head of the ward had requested “the ridiculous white ones.” She was smiling when she said “ridiculous,” and her smile suggested that any surgeon who sneered would be made to fetch a butter knife on a string to open a stubborn window as penance. “If you come Thursday,” she added, “there will be music. Not the kind you pretend to like. A man with a violin who doesn’t mind if he makes us cry and will also know how to play the thing my grandmother called hora lumii.”

At the shop, red and white accumulations made the windows look like a small weather system. Mara tied threads around the necks of birds and refused to make a single pun about string theory, which was how Ileana knew she had been charmed against her will. Viorica turned her bottles so their labels faced the light like faces waiting to be kissed and declared that Mărțișor was a racket and also indispensable. “We bribed spring before we could bribe officials,” she said, pushing a jar of honey forward for prominence. “It never worked as well as we hoped, but at least we invented good knots.”

The city, for its part, felt permitted. Men stopped to look in the window without performing a yawn and then caught themselves and moved on; women came in with the decision to buy already made and only asked permission to enjoy it. An influencer arrived, obligatory as pollen. She had the kind of hair that had a budget, and she pointed her phone at the birds and then at her own mouth and then, mercifully, at the ceiling. “We adore,” she said to the square rectangle, and Mara stood at the counter like a bouncer in a museum and said, “We sell,” which ought to have been a collision and became, instead, a sort of public health disclaimer. The woman hesitated, put her phone down, and bought a violet no one had asked her to love. “For my mother,” she said, a little sheepish in the way of people used to being admired and unprepared for needing to be forgiven. “She hates the internet.” When she left, Mara wrote a note and stuck it on the counter: we do not accept exposure; we tan badly, and they laughed into the soft space it made.

Inspection arrived as all things that begin with a stamp do, unannounced and prepared to be offended. A man whose blazer had outlived two governments whistled through his front teeth at the fire extinguisher and found the kettle cord adventurous and took notes on a pad that had learned to wrinkle its own paper as if it disapproved of what was being written. “Authorization for assembling foodstuffs?” he asked Viorica with a carnivore’s politeness, gesturing to the corner where quince winked in a jar like a slow eye.

“I am not assembling,” Viorica said, standing on her dignity with the grace of a goat on a roof. “I am decanting. The law has yet to learn the difference because it is busy preventing youth from eating seeds on buses. Do you intend to fine me for syrup?” The inspector smiled, which was alarming; he had the smile of a man who learned long ago to enjoy the sound of the word “receipt.” Ileana stepped in with the other kind of smile—the one that offered a binder before he had asked and pointed with relief at a photocopy of a document obtained at the end of a long line where she had had time to design three classes in her head. “Here,” she said. “Authorization for sale of non-therapeutic herbal preparations. Here, the extinguisher, recent and enthusiastic. And here”—she placed a little white bird on his clipboard because she had learned the gambler’s art of the inappropriate—“is a gift for your daughter or your mother or the fine woman at the office who does the work for you. Take it now and then decide if you want to find a problem that doesn’t exist.”

He tried very hard to mind his dignity. He took the bird, regretted taking the bird with the entire right side of his face, and looked around as if a hole in the floor would be polite enough to open under him and allow him to fall away from consequence. “The cord,” he said at last, sighing as if he had hoped to enjoy this more. “You will change it. And you will tell the kettle to respect the electricity. And you will not boil the city with sentiment.” “We will not,” Ileana said, and after he left, the kettle boiled in a fit of pique and they all drank without saying the word “mercy.”

It was the month of mucenici, dough loops that masqueraded as figure-eights and swam in syrup thick with walnuts and orange peel. Mara declared it a religious holiday for her tongue and went missing with a plastic bowl; she returned contrite and sugared and insisted on washing every cup in the place to make up for the syrup that had managed to visit her elbow. On the ninth, Marius told the story of martyrs in a voice flat as the Dâmbovița when wind is in a mood to sulk, and the boys pretended to be bored while memorizing the parts where bones outlasted orders. “Nine,” he said to the gate, as if gates had an interest in arithmetic. “Enough to make a line. Not enough to fool a wind.” He brought a pot of mucenici someone had pressed into his hands in the courtyard—a pot older than whoever had made the pastries in it—and Viorica declared them sinful and asked for a second bowl that she said was for science and did not elaborate.

There were complications that did not present themselves as drama, which made them difficult to take seriously and then, predictably, expensive. The landlord who owned the narrow strip of roof above the shop decided to sell his sky to someone who preferred billboards to light, and for two days men in reflective vests looked at the parapet like a problem that could be solved with a louder voice. “No,” said the old woman with the white hair, who had nerves men respected without discovering they did, and then pointed her cane at the place where rain had always entered the building without first asking how long it could stay. “If you put your metal there, our damp becomes yours. You will inherit mushrooms in your walls. We are generous people. We share everything.” It bought them a week, and within that week Mara found the regulation no one remembered, the one about heritage sight lines and the obligation to pretend dawn mattered, and Ileana wrote a letter that was more elegant than polite, and they wrote “no” on a piece of paper in a font that made the answer feel older than the men’s patience, and the men went away to install their light somewhere else and claim victory.

When she could afford an absence, Ileana took the overnight train east because the wet had lifted for a day and her mother had announced on the phone that she had cooked too much and needed to be prevented from killing herself by thrift. The compartment smelled like old perfume that had learned to live with cabbage. A woman in the upper berth told the story of a man from Tecuci who had built a house alone and had forgotten the bathroom and simply never invited anyone to visit; a boy with a voice that hadn’t decided whether to crack or sing practiced a song under his breath and apologized for nothing. In Focșani, her mother met her in the station like a soldier who had decided to greet peace with an argument. “Why are you so pale?” she asked as if it were a bill. “Do you eat? Do you sleep? You have the face of a saint that no one knows what to do with. Come. I made soup for eight hungry men. You are one.”

The apartment had new curtains she had not asked permission to admire and a plant with leaves the size of someone’s idea of tropical prosperity. Her mother fussed and then sat and then stood and then consented to sit properly, a choreography she would have disapproved of in any other woman. “Your cousin says he saw you on the internet,” she said, rolling the word as if tasting it for poison. “He says you have a shop where paper pretends to be something. He says your hair looks good and that you have lost weight, which is an insult disguised as admiration. I told him to send me the article and I read it and it made me cry because they wrote ‘for the dead’ as if the dead were waiting outside in the cold and you let them in. And also because the photo made you look like a person who stands with her feet apart as if expecting something to try her. Do not stand like that always. Your knees will ache.”

They ate soup and then quince and then the biscuit that acted like a sponge and then, because sentiment insisted, they opened a box in the wardrobe where her mother kept the things she never let anyone believe she had. There were letters from an aunt who had married a man in Canada and discovered that the supermarket could cure certain homesickness and cause others, there was a small packet of paper birds folded by a neighbor with more patience than faith, and there were photographs of Ileana with hair in a fringe that had seemed, at the time, inconspicuous. Her mother pulled out a paper flower, flatter than it had intended to be, yellow dulled to the color of good butter. “We used these,” she said, turning it over as if expecting medicine on the other side. “When sugar was rationed, we decorated with flori din hârtie, and when love was rationed we did not. I made them for your grandmother’s icon, and then I stopped because your father called it ridiculous, and I cannot say he was wrong and I cannot forgive him. Eat more. You will find no forgiveness in your mother’s kitchen.”

On the train back, she wrote a list of things that had to be done before anyone could accuse her of optimism. Buy more tape. Replace kettle cord with a cord that had no interest in heroics. Sign the paper that would let Viorica sell tincture legally in the shop on Thursdays and that would demand eighty euros and a photostated signature from a man in a room over the police station. Teach the class at the institute and prevent the music man from insinuating a violin. Ask the tailor whether his son wanted to learn to cut crepe without frightening it. Ask Marius if it was too early in the year to plant sweet peas against the courtyard fence without insulting the wind.

The institute class took place in a room so white it reflected intentions back at you. A camera on a tripod watched, patient and unthreatening in the way of predators that prefer to depress rather than chase. Women came in wearing the kind of faces you wear when your salary depends on both delight and suspicion. Ileana demonstrated the cut that turned a flat petal into something that would catch light like a truth; she talked about wire as if it were behavior, and tape as if it could be forgiven for being green, and the room slowly forgot to be impressed with its own whiteness. A woman with a pen that had “EU” near its clip asked why paper and not silk, and Ileana made a joke that was kind and then did not. “Because of price,” she said simply, “and because my hands grew up with this and I do not need to become another woman to be good at it. Silk demands ceremonies I am done with. Paper is obedient and then suddenly not. It is like people.” The camera caught her hand more honestly than it caught her mouth. Someone, somewhere, would cut the footage into a minute of sincerity for the internet. It didn’t matter. Three women took scissors home and told themselves that a night could be shortened with cut fringe, and that mattered.

On a Friday that started with a hinge squeaking just to be dramatic, Luminita arrived flanked by two women from the market who wore indignation as if it were perfume gone sweet with age. “They want to raise the rent,” she announced, and her bracelets hardly made a sound. “They say we bring nothing but litter and cheap hats. They say tourists get spooked. They would like us at the back by the shoes that are ashamed of themselves.” She produced a notice printed on paper that had cost more than the thought behind it. “Six months,” she said, “and then double. I told the man who told me that I would teach his wife to cut peonies with her nail, and he said he would prefer a raise.”

The shop became a planning table with tea. Mara wrote on a piece of cardboard with a marker that had minded its cap, not slogans but lists of names—each woman who would care, and each man who would have to be embarrassed into pretending care. Viorica told them which journalist accepted insults with grace and which one insisted you admire his hair before he would lift a pen. The teenager with the scar near his ear volunteered to bring his cousins and made it sound like muscle; the old woman with the white hair said she would come and sit and refuse to be moved and dared them to call the police on her with a look that would have made an ambulance apologize. “We will sell birds at the edge of their clean aisle,” Ileana said, feeling the brief reheated anger that bureaucracy served, “and we will price them so low that their receipts leak and so high that their eyes water, and we will be inconvenient and insist on it.”

They were, and it worked in the way that such things work—bluntly, imperfectly, expensively. A councilor whose face was a collection of courtesies appeared with his hands held just high enough to show he carried nothing; he promised a revision, a reconsideration, a respect. He said the word “Heritage” as if he were freighting it for the first time, and Viorica sniffed like a woman with a better dictionary. The notice that came two weeks later was thinner and more smug; it offered a smaller increase and the privilege of staying where they were if they learned to speak kindly about mops. It was victory edited into survival. Luminita took it, put it in her box under the green tape, and said, “Good. I like fights that end with a joke. Next time, we will make a banner. Perhaps with fringe. They will die of laughter and we will count money.”

The night they got the notice, a storm did the thing they had learned to expect and then it did something else. The lights went down on the entire block, and the usual chorus of complaints rose and then faltered because it was a clean dark, unpunished by sirens. The shop became a cave that had learned polite lighting: beeswax candles, the gold that makes people forgive one another. The birds, freed from the vanity of electricity, moved in a wind that appeared from nowhere and wrote shadows on the wall that looked like a language. A woman who had come to buy a violet stood and cried because she had been waiting to cry for five weeks and this felt like a room that could hold it. A boy found his mother’s hand and was disgusted by himself and did not let go. Marius arrived with a lamp that had known tents and night watchmen and men who loved dogs more reliably than people, and he set it on the counter with the word he used for announcing events that had the decency to be simple. “Snow,” he said in March, and no one argued.

She bandaged his hand again when the lamp toasted it, an old intimacy made newer by the way he kept his palm open without asking for privacy. The scar on his wrist lay quiet in the candlelight. He looked at her with the expression he reserved for estimating if a branch would fall if asked, and then turned his head because he did not like to make people feel inspected. “I will go to the market with you tomorrow,” he said, which either meant he worried she would fight too hard or worried she would not fight hard enough, and she appreciated the ambiguity as a romance of its own. “Bring rope,” he added, as if every situation could be improved by rope, and perhaps he was not wrong.

April threatened to become a drumroll and then remembered to stay rain. The plane tree put out buds like tiny truths. The hospital called for color because someone in purchasing had decided to allow joy as a line item. The institute sent a photograph of hands working and asked if they could use it in a program that would travel to a small town that believed itself untouched by trends and would welcome the arrival of a good one disguised as a class. The tailor returned with photographs of a baby and the faint panic of men who realize that time is not something they can negotiate with once, successfully, and then dismiss. He asked if paper birds were good luck in Spain; Ileana said yes in the tone that allowed a lie to become true in a room if told confidently.

One of the boys brought a football to the shop by mistake and saw it as a test of adulthood to pretend he had meant to. He kicked it against the wall and stopped when he saw a bird quiver. “I did not see it,” he said, outraged at gravity’s presumption. “It did not see you,” Marius answered, not unkindly. “Consider that a peace.” The boy nodded like a man who had come from a meeting and left with notes. He returned the next day with exact change for a single white bell and the face of someone who did not yet understand that buying beauty can be accompanied by the same concentration you use buying bread.

In between, there were the small stabbings the city administers to prevent complacency from getting uppity. A neighbor left a note about garbage in a handwriting that made the complaint seem older than paper, and then apologized for his own anger with a basket of tomatoes that had learned sweetness somewhere they did not care to admit. The internet argued with itself about whether paper flowers were betrayal or salvation, and Mara wrote replies for sport and then stopped because sport can outgrow pleasure in an afternoon. A woman came and demanded they make fifty red roses for a politician’s wife who had the face of a person who despises mercy; Luminita accepted and priced them high enough to make the woman blink and then return with a compliment.

There were also gifts that pretended to be accidents. Viorica fainted, briefly, in the apothecary and woke up furious with her blood for attempting melodrama. “I know what caused it,” she said, calling Ileana later with the self-diagnosis of a woman who trusted her own pulse more than any machine. “Lack of sugar. And the sight of a man crying in my shop without discipline. We will pretend it is nothing and we will train the jars to be heavy at night so I do not carry them like a girl. Do not bring me pity. Bring me the rosemary with the strong stem. The one you bully.”

Ileana brought rosemary and a new ledger because the old one had a spine that had begun to give in, and they wrote in it the simple things that lend dignity to trade: who owed what, who paid, who promised, who would not be asked again. Viorica wrote her name at the top with that neat aggression you associate with primary school teachers and good cooks. “One day,” she said, matter-of-factly, as if describing the weather issuing from long-range forecast, “I will leave this to someone who can count and will not sell sugar pills to women who need soup. It might be you. It might be the boy with the scar. It will not be the idiot with the blazer who believes in vitamins and nothing else. Do not argue. It is unbecoming.”

“No argument,” Ileana said, though the thought of becoming apothecary made a small panicked bird in her chest flutter for the exit. “But do not hurry. The jars prefer you for now.”

Easter came with its eggs pretending to be new planets and its lamb pretending to be innocent. The church bells did the old trick of making the sky feel like a ceiling that had softened. People who resisted sermons came and accepted wax because they wanted to move in a crowd that pretended to know a song. The shop made wreaths with green that did not apologize to winter; they made birds that blushed on purpose; they made lilies that refused funerals for two weeks and then agreed to accompany them because society had to be humored. The old woman with the white hair brought a story about a priest who had tripped and made everyone laugh and forgiving him had saved them all the trouble of inventing love. “Do not look put upon,” she warned the young ones, wrists cocked, “when joy asks for a lift. It is heavy and will sit on the floor if you do not insist.”

One morning, as the river performed its party trick of holding a new sky in parts, a boy from the hospital came into the shop without his mother and with a dignity that refused to be narrated. He was fourteen; his eyes had learned a story that people ten years older told badly. “The lilies,” he said, not trying to get sympathy with his mouth. “They helped my grandfather not hate the room.” He coughed, a necessary punctuation. “He died yesterday, and my mother says she never wants to see them again and also can she keep one. I told her she is allowed both. She is at home and cannot speak to anyone yet. I would like to buy,” he recited, like a sentence copied from a book that had saved him before, “one that looks like it understands that I know two things at the same time.”

They made him one that would look wrong in any photograph and perfect on a windowsill under a calendar with kittens. He paid with money folded so carefully it had learned new geometry. When he left, Luminita leaned against the counter and shook her hands as if shaking water off, a superstition to prevent feeling from sinking into the bone. “We do not deserve our jobs,” she muttered to no one in particular and to half the saints on the wall. “And yet here we are.”

On a warm day that promised heat would be a problem again, the boys insisted on showing Marius the knot they had learned to tie on YouTube and that had convinced them that the internet deserved to exist. He watched, slowed it with his fingers, and taught them the other way, the one his grandfather had forced into his hands until it became preference. “Now,” he said, pressing the ends together and tugging, “you will forget this if you do not use it. Memory is lazy. Put it somewhere it will be forced to work.” To her surprise, he turned to Ileana as if she were another boy with rope and not a woman who made a shop stay honest. “You are tying your days strangewise,” he said. “Make the loop bigger. Leave yourself a way out. You do not always have to be cleverer than the wind.”

She nodded, not pretending to understand, and later, at the river, where the gulls had reclaimed their committee status and the taxis performed their mating rituals at the light, she understood. She wrote a list that was not a chain but a series of small generous instructions to herself: one window open; one day for the hospital without charging; one evening without numbers; one white bird for a neighbor whose voice had been rough with no excuse; one lunch eaten sitting down; one hour to watch steam; one call to her mother where she did not defend; one question to Marius that did not require an answer. She tucked the list under the magnet with the picture long gone and felt as if she had been given rope but not told to hang anything with it.

The day the inspector returned with a second clipboard and a new haircut, he found a class in session and Fleur-de-lis in progress and a woman telling a story about a favor that had, against the rules, been returned. He observed in silence for a minute, then made a note, then adjusted his tie as if to ask permission to speak. “You have become,” he said gravely, as if awarding a medal, “a place where my daughter is safe to say things I cannot hear in my kitchen. For this I will fine you less than the law allows for your plug. It would be a sin otherwise.” He wrote the amount, which was rude and manageable, and left without taking a bird because the dignity he had retrieved after the first one now clung to him out of loyalty.

By the time the acacia remembered how to perfume a street without asking permission, they had made a habit of surviving. The shop had a broom that recognized only one corner as its weakness and leaned there between bouts; the scissors developed favorites among the hands that used them; the radio had been allowed in on Wednesdays when Mara’s patience with her own smart jokes wore thin; the kettle grudgingly consented to a new cord and came to terms with a life that involved discipline. The building association surrendered, through neglect, to the trees. The gate and the hinge took the same measure of each other every evening and agreed to call it friendship. The dog learned to sleep where the sun moved. The Dâmbovița held the moon badly or brilliantly, depending on its own opinion that night. And on a Tuesday that was no one’s birthday and everyone’s, Ileana stood with her hands empty and then full, and said yes to a class that had asked nothing rude, and then no to a man who wanted to hang plastic, and then carried a pot of basil up the stairs, and thought, with the contentment that can only come from a day that obeyed no one and still turned out, that perhaps this was habit enough to be called a life.
